I don't think this is really just at the hotel, but in the waikii area in general. We rented a car for a day and ended up returning it early instead of parking. There were some other factors in this, it's $20 to park overnight. You can park in other locations not to far for $6 - $10 / 10 hrs (overnight allowed).Overall, it was a solidly average hotel. We'd stay there again and thought it was a decently clean, good bang for the buck.

My husband & I stayed at the Imperial thru an RCI exchange Jan 3-10 2013. The one bedroom one bath unit on the 16th floor had 2 lanais, coffee maker,microwave & dorm refrigerator. No coffee was provided but the ABC store downstairs had everything we needed. Didn't prepare any meals while there, just bought sandwiches, fruit & snacks @ the ABC. Unit was clean & garbage removed daily. The only downside was the street noise late at night(yelling/hollering) but we have had that happen even at high end resorts in Waikiki. We will return.

You can't beat the location, but that's about all you can say is great about the Imperial. If you like 1950's style and decor, this is the place for you... think the carpet and furnishings are about that old too. Murphy bed is a double and the sofa is the queen (weird). You can easily walk to many restaurants, happy hours and shopping as well as the beach. Bus stops are near by and shuttle service is available to the airport. ABC store and Denny's were convenient (in the building) and ABC has groceries and other conveniences. If you are looking for location and convenience this is it, it you want a little luxury or want to be spoiled, book somewhere else. The staff was friendly (except concierge), but that did not compensate for the condition of this property.

We will be back at imperial in Feb 2013, this is our 4th visit back, and I just booked extra nights to stay , Not the big fancy places but more like going home, and I love the location, was there back before lewers street had the big make over, from a bad area to now the prime area..love it at Imperial, have stayed at other location but keep going back to where I am treating like Ohana.......Thank you to the great staff and will see you all soon...Sharon

Friendly staff made check in a breeze. In fact the staff was unfailingly cheerful, professional and prompt in all their service throughout the 2 weeks. The condo was clean and had a private balcony, flat screen tv's and a Pullman kitchen that we could make breakfast or a snack and save $$$. Here they provide dish washing soap and coffee filters. Provide your own salt and pepper, coffee, etc.One negative, the ice machine was located in the parking garage and was kind of creepy to go by myself at night, but maybe that's my big city paranoia talking.Two bathrooms, lots of fluffy towels, were nice for two adults traveling together and I loved the soap that smelled of Camomile.26th floor owners lounge has a large balcony and awesome view, great place for a sunset cocktail. Also on that floor is a "for a fee" computer room with games, library and pool table. Good place to entertain your teenagers. I also used the fitness room which was clean, with newer machines and free weights. Didn't use the whirlpool or sauna. The rooftop pool was getting some use but was a bit windy and cool for me. Since it's a short walk to the beach I enjoyed strolling and sunning there.24 hour Denny's and ABC store (offering groceries, drinks and gifts at Whole Foods prices) are on site, very convenient. We also tried the Foodland but prices were comparable to ABC so why go farther? Many good restaurants within walking distance and a couple great happy hour options with food as well.. We are both spoiled foodies, like the finer experience, so we tried Wolfgang's happy hour (reasonable for a few hours very upscale afterward) and Taormisu's which was so good we went twice for dinner! Shopping within one block includes every designer name you've ever seen, but I found a place called Turquoise just around the corner with women's party clothes at ridiculously low prices. The International Bizarre is also waling distance and features beautiful fashions made in Hawaii at reasonable prices. The fabric feels like a tropical breeze on your skin. If you're in town on a Saturday morning be sure and book your table for brunch at The Jade Dynasty Seafood Restaurant at Ala Moana Center. The Center is upscale shopping on the top 3 floors, locals shop in the basement shops, but the legends of live radio, Perry & Price Saturday Morning Show, KSSK AM, is broadcast live on the 4th floor at The Jade Dynasty. It features dim-sum and live entertainment & is really fun.I also shopped at a few of the stores in the hotel lobby and I feel the prices were reasonable and the customer service outstanding.Honolulu is very expensive but the people are nice and the weather outstanding, even in the "winter" months where it's "cold" (the locals all wore jackets but for me it was heaven, 70's-80's F. with a little light rain) it was a great stay at a very nice place.

The hotel is very basic, but provides everything you need. The location is fantastic and although it is not beach front property, it is only about 5 minutes walk to the less busy stretch of Waikiki beach. Everything you want in terms of restaurants and shopping is right outside the door, and there is an extensive convenience store in the building on street level.We booked quite a few tours through the tour desk, who was very helpful. Our pick up locations were either at the front door or around the corner at a central tour bus depot.It's an older property and you can tell because furniture in the rooms very worn/ well used. The kitchen had a coffee maker, but no kettle so we boiled water in a pan on the stove. There is a full stove, mini fridge, microwave and sink. All dishes etc are provided. We had the Hala suite, which can sleep up to six, but only for two people. It was large enough for us, but with more than 4 people I feel like it would be very cramped when everyone is in the suite. One of the bathrooms had very poor lighting making it difficult to use the mirror and the second bedroom is very very small. We had issues with the in room wifi.

Property wonderfully located on Lewers Street. Had stayed here about 10 years ago when Lewers Street was not the upscale street it is now. The property cannot be beat--close to the beach, shopping, so many places to dine, and beautiful 26th floor owner's lounge overlooking the ocean. The unit my husband and I had was a Palm Unit with its own bedroom, sofa bed, and murphy bed. Unit had a small refrigerator, older dial microwave, and small lanai with 2 chairs. We had a unit on a high floor and did not experience any problems listening to traffic below. Carpet and drapery really outdated. Property fit its needs for us, but do not expect upscale accommodations. We rented this unit privately and found the week hard to get accommodations as there was a marathon in Honolulu of 30,000+ people that took alot of hotel bookings + Pearl Harbor remembrances that week. Easy to get to from the airport with airport shuttles available and dropped right off at the lobby door. We did not rent a car this particular week on Oahu--not really needed with all the trolleys or buses available. Did not use the pool on the top floor as we went to the beach. Nice to have air conditioning in the room. Internet was $15 for the whole week and okay speed. Unit just the right size for us. Overall, a decent place to stay.

Great location just off of Waikiki Beach. Banyon room sleeps 6 (bedroom 2, sofa bed 2 and fold down bed 2.) Noise at night if low floor from smoking area out back ( bad location). Good to walk from, Hard Rock cafe just around corner, Denny's and ABC store on 1st floor. Bedroom is small but does the job! Pool on roof and great lounge on 26th floor, kitchen oven for use and tv and eating area. Also pool table and great view from balcony! Good value for $$$$

Prior to booking at the Imperial Hotel in Waikiki, I read quite a few adverse comments on various travel sites about this Hotel. As it was the only Hotel in Waikiki at anything resembling a reasonable price that would allow 3 males to have their own beds in the one suite, I accepted the booking with some trepidation. We stayed there for 10 days and the room was quite good, clean and very acceptable to us. The staff at the Front Desk and Valet Parking areas were first class. Nothing was too much trouble to them. Anyone complaining about this Hotel is very hard to please. This Hotel is positioned in Waikiki to have easy access to all shops, restaurants and transports and has to be the best value Hotel in Waikiki.

This place is a solid stay, I have been to the Imperial about 60+ times and do not own a timeshare. This is a good place if you are wanting clean, cheap, and a close to the ocean sort-of-place. My whole family usually goes (about 10+) and we stay in a few rooms. Great for families as other hotels can get quite costly with the more people you bring in. We were trying to get the same deal on a hotel 6 blocks away, that was MORE expensive and so dingy. Imperial is defiantly the best bang for your buck.Pool:Is on the top level and can get quite cold with the windRooms: Beds are medium-comfy, enough room for lots of guestsLocation:Great location, why we pick the Imperial each time!Staff: Fun, and thoughtfulFood:We go to Denny's at the bottom and get breakfast for $4We also head to the International Marketplace for some fresh Coconut milkWhen we stay at the Imperial it is ALWAYS a family holiday, I don't think I would suggest this for newlyweds or honeymooners

I don't like writing poor reviews about anything but this place is terrible. This is with no disrespect to the staff who try their best to accomodate but this is easily the worst hotel in this area. Again, it hard when you are comparing this hotel amongst Wyndam, Trump and Sheraton, but these are the neighbours and therefore the unfair comarisons begin. I won't go over all the unbarable details with respect to the staff, who again try but the rooms are small, old and nasty. Pay a little more and get something a little better. You will enjoy your time more:(

This is the place to go if you want to be close to the beach, close to the great shops on Kalakaua, on a bus route, steps away from the Royal Hawaiian Mall, the list goes on and on. My mother in law goes for a number of months every year and stays in a Studio suite. Perfect for one or two people. We have stayed in the Palm and Koa units - one bedroom with 2 bathrooms. very spacious, nice kitchen and great views!! As owners we have access to the owners lounge - you can watch the sun set and the whales and dolphins play - roof top pool area is outstanding - amazing views. The new Trump tower condo is a block away - so that should say something about the area. There are three hot tubs, small gym and nice laundry area. Very clean units, comfy beds, amazing staff. If you have the opportunity to stay here, don't hesitate to book it!!

Can you say Ghetto? It's a synonym for Imperial Waikiki. I have stayed in many hotels in Waikiki. My family stayed at the Imperial once before, in 2010 and at that time I thought it would be worth a return visit. How things change! There has been no upkeep and it is refllected in the staff's attitude. The bathroom toilet overflowed, the paint is peeling off the walls in some areas.The day manager Michelle Nahale was rude, unfeeling and unprofessional. She had no sense of family, fun or Aloha. We cleaned the room before checking out...something we have never had to do before at other establishments. But because housekeeping only comes after the 4th day and we stayed 2 nights I did not want to risk losing the 250-dollar deposit. Ms. Nahale told me I would have to forfeit the deposit anyway because a closet door was off its lower sliding track. It was like that when we checked in and easily fixed. I asked for her business card and of course they don't have cards. Let that be a clue, an early warning siren. If the Imperial Waikiki resort is on your radar, JUST SAY NO!

It was in a great location, was a half block from Waikiki beach, and half block from shops and restaurants. Just needed a paint job, newer window treatment (drapes) and needed renovations in the bathroom which is connected to the bedroom.
user_name:
Cutestuff13
New York City, New York

review_body: I go here all the time & love it. We got 7 rooms 3 years ago & are returning this summer to book 8 rooms. Great place for the entire family to have a vacation -- rooms have a minimal kitchen & it is very kid/family friendly. no kid pool, etc, but so close to the beach& everything so it's all ok!

This resort is situated in the middle of it All! Walking Distance to Restuarants, Shops, Waikiki's Newest Beach Walk. Also close to Major Island Tour Shuttle Stop, about a half Block away. Rooms basic, Older decor, but it was comfortable anyway.Staff Very Friendly. We thought when we booked we were going to have a stove in our kitchen. But, All we had was mini-fridge, sink, toaster, coffee maker, and microwave. ABC store next to Lobby very Convenient, but some items very pricey! Parking Valet Only, and add on $25 per night for garage. Very limited street parking Anywhere in Waikiki, and at a cost. We rented Car for 2 days, after that used shuttles, or very reliable Public "The BUS" to get around. Walked Mostly, so bring your comfortable walking shoes. They should change the Name of "Waikiki" to "Walk-kiki" Because you don't have to deal with Traffic & Parking when you Walk!! We booked through Online Travel Site, and when we Checked out, they Charged me an additional $6 per night "resort fee" on top of taxes, etc. No mention Ever made of this Online or when we Checked in. Building 27 stories tall, and If you can Book a room, do so at the highest Floor, Since this town never sleeps, and traffic & pedestrians can be a little loud at night. Would stay here again, just would make sure of All costs, and Room Amneties!!

We stayed at this hotel for 4 days - with the purpose of attending a wedding. The hotel staff were great, very helpful, and the room - while not fancy - was perfectly adequate. Our needs are not great, but we had excellent beds, clean rooms, and an acceptable kitchen. The added bonus was that you can walk to so many great beaches, restaurants and shops right outside the door. Some people complained about the prices at the ABC store on the ground floor, but it wasn't so much different from other grocery stores away from the strip. We don't need 5 star - this was a great place to stay in a great beach area - for a very reasonable price.

You will hear good in this review and you have to understand I am low maintenence and typically do Europe :) We visited with a friend who paid for the resort on her RCI points. We were on the third floor and our patio faced a building and a generator. It sucked but we could dry our suits and towels there. The room was updated with a convection oven, nice counter top, big sinks and great shower. However, we did not care about those things. I was there with 2 friends and my 2 daughters who are in their early 20's. The location worked well because I did not want to rent a car, and at night and it works well because my girls wanted to hit the night life and we enjoy great dinners. We did bus tours (which I typically shun) most days and had a blast; every part of the Island is accessible. The shopping was fun but I would recommend that if you want to leave your money with the real Hawaiians head to the Farmer's Market or local stands on your tours. There is a farmer's market outside of Diamond Head on Saturday mornings I would recommend. Talk to the locals and they will always give you great advise on where to purchase the treasures you are looking for. At the farmers market we purchased nut butter and bread there for the week and tried a lot of local favorites tastes. Get out of the city though - it is amazing and I loved that when I got up at 5 am I could always walk to the beach with my coffee and enjoy the sunrise.

If you just need a place to sleep and freshen up this could be the place for you ! if you are wanting a more luxurious and amenities extravagant menu, would not recommend it. Pay the extra bucks elsewhere if you are not wanting to enjoy the tourist activities and excursions and just hang around the hotel. Stayed here last year for a week, in a different room configuration and with more people, and for a bargain price, using a time share option. This time around chose this hotel for its location, knowing already what it was like, and because we knew the local surrounds. Yes the hotel is an older style, and had a pull down bed as well as a sofa bed. Tiny tiny tiny bathroom, which could be frustrating if staying longer. Did have cooking amenties which we didnt use this time around.Basic hot tub and pool facilities. Awesome views from the room allocated on the 26th floor. Very close to all amenities, beach, food, shopping, and a renovated ABC store directly beneath the hotel. Friendly staff from check in to check out, and also during the night when a foam topper for the mattress was required ! Very good value for the money paid. Did meet someone in the elevator who actually lives there, he was happy with what he pays monthly and the area overall.

So I looked over the comments and pics of other reviewers praying it wont b as bad as da some of da pics ...n to b honest it isn't..yes..its dated...yes its small but hey it's in the middle of everything..location ..location ..location ...incredible..steps from all da high end shopping for all u shoppers of high end stuff..haven't checked everything out yet but u know I m not here in Waikiki to stay in my room and do nothing...this is a no frills condo that will do what we need it to do n for da price we paid, incredible really...can't beat da location...

Although the room we stayed in needed some updating, we were extremely comfortable. Being on a reasonably busy street in Waikiki we found that by using earplugs we were not disturbed at all by any of the usual street noises. However the best part of staying here was the "members lounge" on the top floor, where all timeshare members how had the bad luck, like us to be on the lower floors without views to take in the magnificent sunsets and fireworks on a Friday night.Hawaii is cheap for food and the convenience of being able to purchase alcohol from the ABC convenience store located next door, for less that you can buy duty free was an added bonus. Highly recommend this hotel.

The resort really needs to be completly renovated on all levels...The rooms were so outdated with old furnishings and the bathrooms were just as old...It was like something you would expect 20-25 years ago.The only positive and modern thing in the place was the bed and the flat screen tvs.Other than that..Everything in the room needed replacing....If they want to keep people coming to this hotel, they need to spend the money to update it to the 21st century! the pool was so small too and un inviting.. very noisey..Found it hard to sleep every night .Would not stay here again....

The location is great, close to Waikiki beach about 3-5 minutes and a ABC store next to the lobby. All staff are friendly and helpful. We stayed in the Palm style 1 bedroom suite w/ 2 bathrooms. It is outdated but for the price and location, no complaints here. Kitchen does have fully equipt. Small fridge included. extra fee if you want a full size. Microwave, and dish washer which we did not use.Living room has a HD flat screen tv with dvd player. also which mu daughter used was murphy bed. Just watch out for the corner when the bed is down!! Bedroom has 1full size bed with bathroom and 1 flat screen tv with dvd player. full closet. Balcony has two chairs and 1 small cocktail table. partial ocean view. iOvernight valet parking is $25/night. But overall the unit was good. It served its purpose. Would recommend to those people with a tight budget or just need a place to crash and go.

The location is great, close to Waikiki beach about 8 minutes and ABC store near front door. All staff are friendly and helpful. Interior of rooms are dated and like in 80s including decor, appliances and bathrooms, and you may get a deck, living and dining area very small. For a one bedroom resort, it is very tight, if you use the second fold out bed from the wall, you can't even go to the washr0om since everything is tight. The rooms looks old. Hotel main lobby gives a better look than the rooms that you end up with. Rooms for 1 room suite is very small. 1 double bed only, second double bed is fold out bed located in the living room. when you unfold the bed in the living room there is no room to walk to the washroom. There is a microwave, stove and fridge and sink. No dishwasher (in these days, this is a surprise, where do you not get a dishwasher in a condo style unit). The fridge in our room was leaking water. The ice cube tray is frozen inside the freezer, you can't put anything in it. The TV is HD but the number of channels are maybe 10 or 15. You have to pay for parking at $20 a day (crazy) and it is valet parking so if you leave something in the car then it is a challenge to get it. You have to pay for internet $25 for a week. How much is it to provide this for free, it hardly costs anything? The upside is that you are close to the beach, you can be there in less than 10 minutes. There is an ABC store in the lobby for anything you need but it is very pricy..some items are reasonable and some are ridiculous like the sandwiches are $10 plus. Fruits are insane prices, 3 bananas $2.50. Bottle water is reasonable. You will have to take the location over the amneties with this hotel as you just a boring room.

Perfect location in Waikiki, walking distance from Kalakaua Ave and the beach. The hotel is not a resort, and the amenities are average. A big bonus is the ABC store located on the ground floor - highly convenient. Parking cost us $25, and I believe they washed the car (bonus) but you can find parking along the canal if you want to park for free. The decor is quite old, but the beds were comfortable. The room we had was self contained (kitchenette) which would suit families and those that don't want to have to eat out all the time. Average water views, and we were on the 23rd floor.The most painful part of my experience were the lifts. Being a high rise building (27 or so floors) the three lifts service ALL floors (instead of being split up). What this means is you will wait forever for a lift, which I experienced often especially when getting ice from the machines only located on level 2 or 27 (inconvenient).Overall it was one of the cheaper places which is why we stayed, but Waikiki will always be expensive. You could probably get better value for money elsewhere as there is nothing special about this location other than location and having an ABC store only a lift ride away.

"We just finished our two week, too long, stay at the "resort" (THIS IS NOT, I REPEAT, NOT A RESORT IN ANY WAY, SHAPE, OR FORM), and as advertised, it is in Waikiki. It's also woefully outdated; bathrooms look and feel like late 60's Holiday Inns'. They remind me of childhood vacations with the parents in South Dakota. Unfortunately, that's not what I look for in a multi-hundred $$/day "resort". Rooftop pool is tiny at best. I wondered about the property when I went to their website before we came, it too looks like it's from the 70's (yes, I know the internet didn't exist in 70's). Turns out the website is on par with the rest of the property. On site restaurant is a Denny's, which seems highly appropriate. Concierge Michael quickly volunteered he could not give any advice on activities not booked through him, guess he didn't want to lose the commission. Such a helpful young man. I doubt other area accommodations charge $50/week for internet access, nor $6/day mandatory fee for the "free" local phone calls. Will say the valet parkers are efficient. Good thing as you're required to use them for a bargain $125/wk (plus tips of course). The "kitchen" (kitchen is a stove top that looks like it belongs in a 60's era Winnebago, microwave, and minifridge that almost freezes ice cubes) sink in our unit started loudly belching water out, eventually discovered an issue in unit above us. Of course, we had to call twice, guess the first maintenance person I asked forgot or something. When we got back after maintenance was in our unit, we were greeted by a sign in hall warning of wet floor, and true to advertising, our floor had a pool of water. Wondered why they left it for me to clean up rather than mop it themselves, perhaps that was another extra charge. If you come here, be fully advised this is nowhere near comparable to nearby properties, and has a host of "gotcha" extra fees. Yes, management was apologetic, and comped internet service and parking for our continued issues, but that didn't improve the nonfunctioning shower in one bathroom, the constant nighttime noise of slamming doors, or the complete lack of any amenities (other than limited selection of DVD's available for the low, low price of $3/night). If you miss those 60's Holiday Inn vacations with your family, however, and cost is no object, this just might be the place for you!"

The location is ideal, right across from the beach. All staff are amazing, from front desk to housekeeping to valet. Interiors of rooms are very 80s including decor, appliances and bathrooms, but our room had a deck, living and dining area, bathroom in each bedroom and closet in bigger bedroom. Everything was clean and housekeeping does a great job with what they have to work with.I don't go to Hawaii to stay in the room so the outdated decor not a big deal. Make sure to request the extras "available on request" such as blender and rice cooker. Keep in mind you'll have to pay for wifi and a normal size fridge if you want a real freezer or space to store fridge food. Room came with mini fridge but you can upgrade for $25.

Excellent location in midst of waikiki. Loved walking to nearby coffee shops, restaurants and shopping malls. However one bedroom suite was less than desirable. Tiny rooms! Showers were smaller with strange odor from either shower stall or water. Furnitures seem old. At least the beds were firm and comfortable. Stubbed toes too often on wall-floor bedframe in livingroom.

We stayed in a Banyan Suite on the 10th floor with a lovely view of... the Embassy Suites across the street. The exterior looks okay, but the interior and especially the rooms leave a LOT to be desired. Rooms are in serious need of an update. We will never, ever stay at the Imperial again. There are many other condo-style accommodations in Waikiki. It will be well worth it to pay a bit extra per night than this place. We didn't take advantage of the kitchenette as we only used the room to sleep and get ready since it was so disgusting and uninspiring. This place was a big wrinkle in an otherwise awesome vacation. PROS:- The front desk and valet staff were very nice, attentive, professional, and knowledgeable. - ABC Store downstairs.- 27th floor pool deck was decent. - Location: It's close to A beach. (Not the best section of Waikiki Beach though.)CONS:- When we walked in, we thought it was Golden Girls, but had not been updated since 1987! The green carpeting was old, gross, and faded near the windows. Oh yeah, it was coming up from the walls where the staff has pulled up the carpet to stuff electric cords down there. Isn't that illegal or against some code? The wicker furniture was equally gross, uncomfortable, and in need of an update. - The bathroom was TINY! It made me think I was in an RV. You could use the toilet and wash your hands at the same time. Oh yeah, the "dusty rose" color of the toilet was equally 1987, but hey, it worked. The wallpaper was so outdated. How much would it cost to replace that?!- The bedroom had a hard double bed. You will probably have to walk sideways to get around it and in to the main area of the bedroom. There is about a foot of clearance between the bed and the wall. It just doesn't seem right.- Being on the 10th floor affords no views. Our unit was also on the Lewers side, so we got street noise (with sliding doors closed) from trash trucks and their back up beeps early in the morning. Noise from drunk patrons at Yard House at the mall (Beach Walk) across the street was also annoying. - Location. You will be in the middle of the outdoor mall on Lewers Street, full of mainland chains and nothing of interest. I can go to Cheesecake Factory, PF Changs, and Yard House back home... The beach closest to Imperial is in front of the Outrigger Reef. It's not the best part of Waikiki - kind of the outskirts in my opinion. - Hot tubs. We visited the hot tubs and felt like it was a temporary location. There are two backyard style hot tubs on some random patio with ugly/ghetto green awnings. Oh yeah, the hotel workers take their breaks and smoke just below the 3rd floor hot tub area, so you get some great secondhand smoke with your tradewinds. Don't do it!
Rust and mold in the bathrooms! This place iis disgusting; and of course " they"re 100% full". This property does not belong in RCI.

The hotel itself is nothing to write home about, but the location can't be beat. We stayed in a 1 bedroom/ 2 bathroom timeshare suite a while back. It had a full kitchen, pullout sofa bed and a murphy bed in the living room. First time sleeping on a murphy bed, and it was an interesting experience, but I digress. It was touted as "sleep 6" comfortably, but I was surprised at how small the unit was. It was a challenge staying a whole week with spouse, two young kids and the IN-LAWS (!). To top it off, there was a lot of construction going on in and around the building. We actually had workers ON/ IN our lanai doing some kind of work the whole time we were there. Since it was Spring Break and the hotel was completely sold out, the management couldn't switch rooms for us. Needless to say, that was a bummer. The great location of the property made up for all the negatives. It was very convenient to the beach, the bus stop, and shopping. There's also an ABC store right next door. The view from the owner's lounge was great but the rooftop pool was meh. We're going back to Oahu in a couple of weeks, but don't think we'll be back to the Imperial of Waikiki.

This hotel is all about the location, it is right in the best area. The rooms are very small and not the cleanest around. If this was not a time share exchange there is no way I would pay for a stay. The bar at the top of the hotel was very nice with a great view. I had a king room that had a very small bedroom, the hotel agreed to move us, this room had two twin beds with more space. If you are looking for a hotel right in the mix this is it, GREAT LOCATION!

This review is for the 1-bedroom that I stayed in for a week (nice). Prior to my friend’s arrival I stayed in a studio for 3 days (horrible). See my other review for the studio. This is the 5th time I have stayed at The Imperial.Room: “Banyan” Unit 905: Light, bright, clean. Peek-a-views of ocean from the deck, but really just views of other hotels (I know from experience, higher floors can have great views). Small true one bedroom with queen bed, and a pull out sofa and Murphy bed in the living room. It could sleep six(!), but it is more ideal for two single friends, or a couple with kids. Linens and beds were clean and comfortable. Kitchenette was modestly stocked with utensils. Convection microwave, toaster, fridge and coffee maker are good for snacks, but I really wish it had a cook-top. In a pinch, you can go to the owners lounge and use their stovetop if you can find pots/pans.Service/Staff: Accommodating. Polite, but not particularly outgoing, warm or friendly. Occasionally a single person at the front desk could not efficiently handle the line of guests.Amenities: Good weight room, sauna and nice rooftop pool. An owner’s lounge on the top floor is a nice place to relax and take in panoramic views. Overnight parking is reasonable for Waikiki at $25/nt. No free Wi-Fi, Lan connection for pay.Location: Premium. The Imperial is an excellent location in the middle of Waikiki. 1 block to the beach, steps to all shopping, restaurants and amenities.All in all, the micro-location and floor level can make or break a vacation, but otherwise a fair value for a clean and quiet home in the middle of Waikiki.As always; I travel to Waikiki several times a year, I can advise that Waikiki is a nice tropical urban adventure. The city comes with the negatives of a big city, along with the overwhelming benefits of a beautiful beachfront resort. Generally, everything in Waikiki is “a little tired” although there have been continuous improvements in the last few years. If you are traveling solo, take Roberts Hawaii from the airport for $12 (no rsvr rqd). Two or more people, take a taxi from the airport to the hotel (should be under $40). In Waikiki, nearly everything is walking distance or a short shuttle/bus away. If you need a car for the day, you can rent one in Waikiki.

This is our second time at Imperial. This time, we used time share exchange points to get a KOA room. This was a 1 bedroom with two bathrooms. We also were able to get an upper floor, with almost unobstructed ocean view. We had room 2007 which was a corner unit with south- and west-facing windows. Great to watch the boats and surfers, then to see the sunset. This is a huge improvement to the room we got in 2010 were we were stuck in a low level room facing east (Waikiki Parc hotel). It was spacious for a family of 4.The only issues were the out-dated airconditioning and old windows which did not shelter us from heat and street noise as well as they should. Every morning, we were woken up at 6am with sound of garbage trucks on Lewers Street. The lanai was very small and not pleasant due to all the traffic noise. I have been told that some units have been renovated, but this is not one of them. Kitchen appliances and bathrooms are still old.However, you can't beat the location. ABC store downstairs has been expanded and renovated since 2010. It has everything you need -- very convenient. Staff are friendly, especially the valets who park the car for us. They know us by name and always make an effort to engage the kids. We will be back.

Ok so yes the decor is old. It's like staying at Grandma's beach house. For the money there is nothing even close to the space and amenities. We stayed with four adults in a 1BR, 2 Bath. We had a small balcony with ocean view Over the Halekulani. Steps to my favorite spots on Waikiki. Beach Walk, Hilton Village, and the Banyan courtyard at the Sheraton. Convenient foot wash in the garage on the way to the beach. Surf Leason shack right there!!We kept the fridge in the room stocked which made it easy to refresh drinks while not losing our spots on the beach. One of us could run and bring down a couple more rounds. We did microwave some oatmeal for breakfast at first but the went to a market and ate fresh fruit the rest of our stay. (not much cooking) The pool is small but who swims there when at the beach?! We ordered salads to go one night and ate on the balcony of the owners lounge. It was the cheapest meal with the best view our entire trip. Look at other places with these amenities on Waikiki and you will easily double or triple what we spent. We bought our week outright from an owner listing on VRBO and he charged us $100 per night. Suddenly pastel colors and ratan furniture didn't look so bad to us! The owners lounge, location, and view sold us. I think people complaining must not get to Waikiki often enough to appreciate what a hidden gem this place is!

Stayed here for a week with friends as they are owners of this TimeShare Property. The location is top notch. Lots of shopping, restaurants, entertainment all right outside the front door. The ABC store located in the lobby is larger than most with food, beverages etc. The beach is only a few minutes walk away. You can walk to most places very easily. The owners lounge is a nice gathering place with pool tables, TV, Kitchen etc. The pool is small and on the 27th floor and its breezy up there. The bar on the top floor isnt open every evening but if its open dont miss it. The view is spectucular and the drinks and decor is top of the line. I only wish the rest of the resort was a nice. The rooms, decor, furniture were old and dated and need of total renovations. We had a two bedroom and two bathroom unit. The master bedroom had 2 double beds and its own bathroom & balcony, the other bedroom was very small only room for the bed & closet. Both rooms had flat screen TV's in addition to the large TV in the living room. The living room & dining room were large complete with balcony. The appliances (coffee maker, toaster, microwave) were new. The refrigerator was very small and the stove top & oven I have havent seen since the 70's. Even the thermostats units were old and outdated. the staff was helpful. We only found valet parking available at the hotel so between paying for the parking ($100 per week) and tips daily it gets pricey.

This is not a resort. It's a condo association that rents out rooms (yet they still charge you a resort fee????). When you book the lowest category you almost invariably get an upgrade to a better room. Hence the good reviews. When you happen to book during Pro bowl week you get what you pay for (ie no upgrade) ....and it's nothing like the reviews have led you to believe.Frankly we did not get the upgrade and were sorely disappointed. Our room was no different than a condo on the beach in Fort Lauderdale circa 1950. Bland, no Hawaiian theme, no resort, no balcony view (it was just a white wall 15 ft across the street), and the Murphy bed collapsing in the middle of the night was quite interesting. We were booked for two nights and stayed only one (we couldn't find another place at 1 am in the morning, night one. Although we tried).Clean? Yes. Basic? Yes. Would I recommend it? Absolutely not AT THE LOWER PRICE LEVEL.

Myself, my two sisters and our cousin stayed here for two weeks in April. The building location scores a 100%, it is perfect. Two minutes walk to the beach (just across the road and down the beach walkway). ABC store and Denny's in lobby. Surrounded by stores and restaurants and only a two minute walk to the main street. The rooms are comfortable and clean but tired and in major need of remodelling. The owners lounge is very comfortable if you do have a late flight. There is comfy couches, TV, kitchen with tables, pool table. There is also a bar upstairs that has a amazing view, it is just too bad that it is only open on week nights and sometimes closed if they have a private function.I love the fact that this hotel is very reasonable and is surrounded by hotels that cost at least twice as much.

Myself and 2 friends stayed at the Imperial for 15 days on a RCI exchange and had the best time ever. Right in the heart of Waikiki. We stayed in a studio room on the 26th floor next to the owners lounge which was very comfortable. Had a great view. Had everything we needed.Very friendly and helpful staff. Everything in walking distance. We used the bus service and tour buses and everything ran on time!!! Bus service has been voted #1 in the US and I believe it.We used the pool alot on the 27th floor. Very quiet and relaxing compared to the hundreds of people on Waikiki Beach. Would definitely stay at the Imperal again

We traded into the Imperial through RCI. Overall, we were very pleased. As others have said, the location canʻt be beat. Itʻs right in the heart of Waikiki with an ABC store in the building and beaches are just across the street.We were in unit 1104, which is a handicap unit, so the layout was a little different. As everyone says, the decor is dated and tired. But the unit was clean enough and everyone on the staff was friendly and helpful. There are only 3 elevators & it can be a bit of a wait sometime. Laundry facilities on the second floor were serviceable and reasonably priced. There is a footwash available in the back of the building, which is great after being on the beach. We were on the Diamond Head side & I didnʻt have any issues with the noise, although there was a jack hammer one morning.Because we traded in through RCI, we were able to use the owners lounge on the 26th floor, which is a very nice perk. The lounge is at the front of the building and has a kitchen, large screen TV and pool table. Views are terrific. We were able to use the lounge after we checked out on our last day, which was great since we had a late flight.Because of the late flight, I requested a late check-out & was given the room until 6:00 for $66, which seemed fair. It was nice to be able to use the room after exploring Honolulu for the day. After we checked out, they were able to store our luggage until we left for the airport.
user_name:
PrettyKitties
North Carolina Coast, North Carolina

review_body: The Imperial Hawaii is one of those places that I would classify as a well-kept secret. My wife and I stayed in a one bedroom unit for two weeks in March and let me tell you that dollar for dollar it can't be beat. If you travel with a budget in mind then the Imperial is the only choice. The staff, whether at the front desk, housekeeping or valet, was always very friendly, courteous and always willing to go that extra step to make you feel welcome or assist you. The unit was clean, quiet and comfortable. The bed provided a comfortable night’s rest and the kitchen was amply equipped. Location, location, location. How can you go wrong being right off of Waikiki Beach. The Beach is just a short block away and a great place to spend the day reading a book, snoozing, swimming or walking along the beach. After a day at the beach, you can return to your unit and either enjoy a home-cooked meal prepared in your personal kitchen or simply walk to some of the best restaurants in the area. The area offers a wide variety of cuisine in a complete range of prices. Like to shop? The hotel is located right in the middle of shopping mecca; from the International Market to specialty boutiques. The roof-top swimming pool is a favourite place for sun-worshippers to gather. On an exchange? At the end of the day, go upstairs to the Owners Lounge, mingle with fellow travelers, take in a beautiful sunset and even watch fireworks (usually on a Friday). Bang for the buck? Our buck stops here.
Rooms are dirty yuck. Got here an the sink was backed up popcorn on floor spider in bed and dryer up puke on the toilet great location though

I just returned from a week in this place. IT was an exchange from my existing timeshare in Cancun. I was hoping for similar to what I have in Cancun but that did not happen. We had a 1 bedroom Banyan suite. It has a queen bed in the bedroom ( looks more like a full bed) a full murphy bed, and queen pull out sofa (horribly uncomfortable). We had 3 adults and my 4yr old daughter. It was a tight fit. They say it is good for 3 but really 2 is best. Not necessarily a family place... I did not get a welcoming family feeling especially when I took my daught to the roof top pool. We were in 802, I personally did not sleep well our view was of the back alley and trucks start coming in about 4 am. The tour busses are coming in about 6 am. It is very close to the tour bus pick up location at the Sheraton just right around the corner in alley so that is convient for touring. There is no kitchen just a convection microwave, small sink, and mini fridge. We ususally prefer to cook ourselves. THere are tons of restaurants in a very short distance. Cleanliness leaves a bit to be desired. THe floors are dirty looking, the decor is old. They only come once a week to clean your room. The rest of the time you have to go down to housekeeping to request new linens and pick them up. Ice machine is on the 2nd floor in the garage or the 26th floor.  Upon Check in if you have an exchange they have to take your credit card info for a $100 deposit up front. but it was not charged to me just the daily room tax. If you have to print anything at the front desk it is $.50/page. With the owners Exchange you get access to the owners lounge on the 26th floor which is nice and has a nice view of beach. THe staff was nice but not outgoing but you could tell they had good relationships with the people who come often. The tour concierge Michael in the lobby was very good and booked everything for us. Through him I recommend on your first days take the majestic circle Island tour and the Polynesian Culture Center tour. They show you places you will want to go back to the rest of your trip.  Would I use this place again If I had not other options but I would have to get a larger suite if one is available because the family.

We recently returned from a week at the Imperial (corner of Kalia and Lewers) in Waikiki. This was our 7th trip to Hawaii and 4th trip to Oahu. One of us stayed on Lewers Street 30 years ago (in a place since torn down) so it was quite interesting to see the changes.The location (across from the Halekulani on the beach side and Roy's/Trump/Embassy Suites across Lewers) is hard to beat. Just steps from the beach and in the middle of all the *happy hour* activity in the area. Plenty of places to eat, drink, walk, relax, etc.Also, our favorite haunt while there was the ABC Store down below. You can get everything there --- food to fix in the unit, juices/alcohol/souvenirs/clothing ---- everything. That ABC store became like home to us during our stay. There are also some clothing/jewelry/souvenir stores adjoining the lobby, as well as a Denny's which we wouldn't normally eat at but the rain was so heavy while we were there that we actually DID eat at the Denny's one night and the food was pretty good.I can't say enough about the bell staff. The regular desk staff was good but the bell guys who you work with to move your car back-and-forth OR to call a cab ---- OUTSTANDING. Friendly, polite, efficient, helpful. They don't get any better. I loved those guys.We rented a car for two days (parts of 3 days --- 48-hours) and because we got the unit on an RCI exchange (thus I guess we qualified for a timeshare parking rate), we paid $20 for two days of parking. Obviously, we gave the guys well-deserved tips. It was cheaper than I expected and so easy to leave the keys with the guys.The hotel has a pool up on top and a couple of hottubs on the 3rd floor, along with a sauna and fitness room there. We didn't use any of those as the weather was so awful --- constant rain. But, they are there and we did check them out. We paid for the DSL internet. The Imperial didn't have wireless available. Internet was $15 a week which we were happy to have since we needed to change all our plans, due to the weather. Very handy to have access for a lot of quick Googling.As far as the unit, we got what we reserved (an RCI trade) and it had many amentities (Palm unit --- 2 baths, 2 flatscreen TV's, DVD players, full kitchen, 2 extra beds as fold-outs, etc.) but, frankly, it was a dump. Except for the new Mr. Coffee coffeepot and the flatscreen TV's, everything else in the kitchen was very old and dated. The stove and dishwasher and microwave looked so old, I didn't use them. Fixtures are dated. Cabinets are very dated and cheapo particle board. Furniture and tile and bath counters were very old and looked dirty or very tired. There was a huge chip (chunk out of) in a bath counter.It's possible that the unit we had was one which had never been upgraded as we did see pictures of other units in the building which were more modern and less tacky. Also, there are a lot of mirrors in the unit which make it look bigger than it was, in the advertising.Our unit (2004, on the 20th floor) is about 520 square feet (we measured it) and did have two tiny balconies, but the unit backed out to the Waikiki Parc and the Sheraton (with a small ocean view between the Sheraton and the Halekulani) and seemed to be in an elevator shaft-type space. In other words, down below were the generators (and garbage-collection centers) of all the high-rise hotels and we could not open the balcony doors without being overtaken with a huge roar of noise.All in all --- we appreciated the location and the staff (and the comfortable bed in the tiny bedroom) but our unit was a *blast from the past* (old and tired) and not relaxing. We're not so picky on the view but it would have been nice to have a little more quiet out on the balcony, so that we could open the patio doors without being blasted with high-volume urban generator noise. Maybe they'll upgrade unit 2004 soon? It sure needs it.

Can't say any more (or enough) about the location, it's perfect. Close to everything you need in Waikiki, incuding the beach. The hotel (or resort, however you want to describe it) is an older building but is clean and comfortable. We stayed in a Palm suite for a week (Interval exchange) and it is quite comfortable for 2, not sure I would want to stay with 4 and definitely not 6 as advertised. Other big pluses are ABC Store on site (although you can find 20+ more within a 10 min walk), Denny's on site (a tad expensive but open early), owner's lounge on the 26th floor has magnificent views (yes it is available to exchangers, no it is not available to renters). About the only negative I can think of is although they have 3 elevators, they are all pretty slow. All in all the Imperial helped make the first Hawaii vacation a very enjoyable one. The hustle of Waikiki was fun, off to the Big Island for a quieter second week (Kona Coast Resort review coming soon).

The Imperial's location can't be beat for downtown action, catching excursions or hopping on the trolley. Waikiki means shopping and restaurants, it is not the carribean vacation you have experienced in the past. Definitely do the cirlce island tour on your first day and then make plans to go back to Haunama Bay to do the snorkelling, this is where you'll get the most kick for your buck and experience. The beach is a city block away, what beach there is..remember Waikiki is a manmade beach. The hotel has a pool on the roof top that is the same size as most homes. It is incased in cement walls with no view, windy. The hot tub facility is a joke, with two home style hot tubs on the 3rd floor, only one worked.The hotel staff is great and friendly, a Denny's is located next door. This hotel needs to do some upgrading, it is very functional but small. Do not stay in a studio, even for two people!!! We stayed in a Banyan and it fit us and our luggage. Waikiki is a touring holiday, not a beach holiday.

The hotel room was upgraded to an ocean view by someone in reservations. The view was spectacular. We rented a car and felt the conceirge desk would have preferred that we book our tours through their services, not very helpful at all. Best advice we received was from our rent a car agent at the airport. Three wonderful places for dining were recommended. Also, used the Internet, Trip Advisor for other places to see & dine.Breakfast @ the hotel was $30 pp and dinner $60 pp. A bit pricy. Do not go @ Christmas, it drizzeled everyday except one.

Preface: I booked a studio for 3 days for myself. When my friend arrived I moved to a 1-bedroom for a week. See my other review for the 1-bedroom.Service/Staff: Accommodating. Polite, but not particularly outgoing, warm or friendly. Occasionally a single person at the front desk could not efficiently handle the line of guests.Amenities: Good weight room, sauna and nice rooftop pool. An owner’s lounge on the top floor is a nice place to relax and take in panoramic views. Overnight parking is reasonable for Waikiki at $25/nt. No free Wi-Fi, Lan connection for pay.Location: Premium. The Imperial is an excellent location in the middle of Waikiki. 1 block to the beach, steps to all shopping, restaurants and amenities.Studio room, Unit 301 : Clean but Horrible. Dark, dank, depressing and noisy. Located 1-foot from housekeeping’s door, 3 feet from the staffs changing room, and next to the sauna, spa, and gym, doors were always banging/sqeeking, opening and closing 24 hours a day. The patio of 301 was covered with a tarp. No light, no view. Situated on a alley, workers on smoking breaks could be heard at all hours. This room should not be available to guests. It should be storage. In fact, all rooms on the 3rd floor should be avoided. At over $100/nt, there is no value in these rooms. If I had to stay more than 3 days in this room, it would ruin a vacation.Please see my other review of Unit 905.As always; I travel to Waikiki several times a year, I can advise that Waikiki is a nice tropical urban adventure. The city comes with the negatives of a big city, along with the overwhelming benefits of a beautiful beachfront resort. Generally, everything in Waikiki is “a little tired” although there have been continuous improvements in the last few years. If you are traveling solo, take Roberts Hawaii from the airport for $10 (no rsvr rqd). Two or more people, take a taxi from the airport to the hotel (should be under $30). In Waikiki, nearly everything is walking distance or a short shuttle/bus away. If you need a car for the day, you can rent one in Waikiki.
Typical timeshare with need for update. Nice staff, convenient location.

Stayed for seven nights with family (2 aduts, 2 teenagers). One bedroom with fold down bed in lounge was cosy, but as the location was excellent, we didn't spend a lot of time in the room. Roof top pool was good, as was the bar / lounge on level 27, especially for a viewing the Friday night fireworks from the Hilton Village resort. Decor is a bit dated, but great value for money.

We just stayed 9 days in the hotel in a one bedroom Banyan suite on an exchange through Interval International. It is not a 4 star hotel by any means and is pretty outdated to say the least but the room was nice and the bed was very comfortable. The location is one of the best in Waikiki and close to beach, shops and restaurants. You can certainly get by without a car but you do need one to see the rest of the island which is beautiful. We had a problem with little tiny ants in the kitchen and bathroom areas in our room at one point and management was excellent and very accommodating. They switched our room to a top floor suite and we never had a problem after this. Aside from that issue we had a great stay. I would stay here again and would recommend it to others.

I booked this hotel for my daughter and her friend as it was in close proximity to the beach and across the road from where we were staying at the Embassy. For the price paid ($111 + taxes and service fee) it offered a good budget alternative. I stayed one night when my daughter was ill to look after her. Her room on the 10th floor overlooking Lewers Street was very noisy and showed signs of age and neglect.There was rust on most of the bathroom fittings and the sheets and towels were worn, faded and stained. However, the room itself appeared to be cleaned well, though the carpets were overdue a steam clean. A friend stayed on the opposite side of the hotel though overlooking the Sheraton and this side of the hotel was much quieter and from the balcony (and pool deck) offered great sea views (Floor 21).Security was lacking somewhat as the keycard access on the elevators had been disabled meaning anyone could access floors. Housekeeping was sporadic as was front desk service.Overall a good hotel for anyone wanting a cheap, no frills hotel close to the beach.

Only stayed here one night but the place was a good value. The elevator was high tech but when I walked into the room, seems like the kitchen was stuck in the 80s. Ancient oven, decent microwave and fridge, Wicker furniture. Some parts of the bathroom seemed unclean- it was bearable.

I have recently stayed at the Imperial for 5 nights and i must say, although my first night's experience was less than ideal, the subsequent 4 night stay definitely made up for itPros- excellent location - behind the Halekulani and at the doorstep of wonderful restaurants on Lewers street/Beachwalk ( eg Roys), you can't beat this place for location. It is very close to the beach, close to trolley stops (including the pink line shopping trolley to take you to the Ala Moana shopping centre)- spacious studio (Ohia suite) - sleeps 4 (although this would be cramped - better for 2 people), standard fit out but very good kitchen facilities, large balcony- in room safe/iron/ironing board- comfortable Murphy bed- courteous and helpful staff (see below)- great deals available - $95 per night (pre-taxes) (via booking.com)Cons- i do not recommend the rooms on level 3 adjacent to the Housekeeping area - due to the volume of foot traffic (staff with their trolleys and coming in and out of their changeroom, and guests - to pick up extra towels etc), it was very noisy. To the Imperial's credit, when i pointed this out, they changed my room the next day As previous guests have stated, the rooms higher up definitely have the better viewsI did not use the pool/sauna so cannot comment (and as the beach was so close by, i didn't feel the need)All up this is a place I would definitely stay at again. It is not a 5 star hotel (and is not pretending to be) - but stay here if you value convenience and amenities at a great price!

We love to travel! And we love a good hotel. This was not the best place we've stayed but it was very good. The room was big enough and the ammenities were acceptable. The price was excellent and we were right in the thick of the Waikiki night life, close to the beach and a million places to eat. The highlight of our trip was Chase Hawaii Rentals, where we were treated as if we were family. They hooked us up! Spent 8 hrs riding Harley's around the island! The customer service was outstanding! A big mahalo to Nick! We strongly suggest that if you need a bike, car, scooter or wanna go with the big bikes that you go thru Chase Hawaii! Next time we will rent for the entire stay.Over all, a great trip!

This was my first trip to Hawaii. I can't imagine a better location to enjoy all that Oahu has to offer than the Imperial. It is located right next to the Beachwalk, and within easy walking distance of numerous restaurants and world class shopping. Views from the lower floors are limited, but the owner's lounge and surrounding balconies on the 26th floors provide some of the greatest views on the island, including awesome sunsets and a front-row seat for the Friday night fireworks from the Hilton. The lounge is equipped with ample soft furniture, a full kitchen, huge flat screen TV, pool table, and guest computer stations.I purchased a studio timeshare unit this year, and because of the timing, was able to stay for two weeks. The staff were extremely helpful and courteous, check-in and check-out were a breeze. The room was very clean, with full maid service three times during my stay, with daily trash pickup and towel exchange. The rooftop pool on the 27th floor and the hot tubs on the third floor balcony were also nice. There is also a guest laundry and workout room. An ABC store on the first floor provided easy access to purchase snacks, gifts, beer, wine, spirits, etc.Some of the more upscale restaurants within a block or two include Roy's, the Ocean House, Ruth Chris, and several upscale Asian, Italian, and Steak houses. The city bus is cheap and very reliable, and several shuttle services and hop-on/hop-off services (Aloha Bus, Trolleys) provide inexpensive alternatives to cabs for areas beyond walking distance. Rental cars are also readily available nearby.The concierge service in the lobby is very good, and can arrange any type of trip or adventure you desire. Most trips/tours provide transportation from the hotel as part of the package.There is a Denny's on the first floor of the hotel that is a good option for inexpensive breakfast or lunch. Also, across the street in the Outrigger Reef, next to the upscale and very good Ocean House, is the Shorebird restaurant. They have a good breakfast buffett for $14 and a unique dining experience in the evenings. You place your order for steak, chicken, mahi-mahi, etc and they bring it to you very rare, in fact, raw. You then join your fellow diners around a huge grill and cook your entree. There is a chef there to assist if needed and all the spices, sauces, etc you can imagine are provided, along with a great salad bar that also includes hot side dishes. All ocean front. If you are an early diner, you can take advantage of their sunset special, which includes a half-pound steak and all the trimmings for $14.95.Several restaurants offer happy hours and sunset specials that significantly reduce the cost of dining out. For example, the Ocean House has its wonderful prime rib dinner for under $20 if you are seated by 6:00 p.m. Giovanni's around the corner has $5 pizzas and appetizers (plenty for a meal), the Yard House has half-price menu selections (not to mention 135 beers on tap), and perhaps my favorite, Top Waikiki (a revolving restaurant) has $4 martinis and $7 appetizers that are huge twice an evening, and the views are the same as they are for the $50 dinners. Duke's Canoe Club in the Outrigger Waikiki Beach is very good and reasonable, and has great beachside entertainment Friday through Sunday from 4-6. Their Hula Pie is to die for.Some of the excursions I arranged through the concierge were terrific: Germaine's Luau, Circle Island Tour and Polynesian Cultural Center, day trip to Maui, North Shore Beaches, Kualoa Ranch were my favorites. My favorite day, however, was renting a convertible and driving around the island, stopping at the East Shore sites, visiting Giovannis Shrimp Truck, seeing the big waves on the north shore.......all at my own pace.Again, my first trip to Hawaii, but it won't be my last. And the Imperial will be my choice for lodging.

I liked this hotel as it is close to beach areas and lies in mid city area which is close to all facilities around with stunning views from the top floors. Some good shopping centres, restaurant and bars are around here. Good value of money as you can get cheaper room, studio type with kitchen facility to suiteroom.

Really well furnished, great pool on the 27th. We were on honeymoon 250010km from home,12 hours time difference. People were very kind, service was great. Shame it's so far awayfrom France, otherwise we would come again. We'll try. And after a week here we went to Big Island but can't remember the name of the hotel there.We were the in december 2005 but in the select window you have got that year

we stayed imperialfor the 2nd time this yeatand it as still as good as pefore the location is so good next door and across the road fron trumps roys ruth chriss chans all within 1 block the staff were great we would like to go back

This "timeshare" hotel is a bit tired but is clean, comfortable and affordable. The service was excellent from the valets, the reception staff and the housekeeping. The suite was large and comfortable and has two TV's and CD/ DVD players. Air conditioning was adequate.Kitchen area was well equipped and cooking facilities were good, but the bathroom was tight.

We just returned from renting the Imperial Penthouse condo 2702 and stayed for 8 nights. This penthouse is on the 27th floor, same floor as the pool and also the same floor as a separate event venue. Check in was quick and we were able to settle in right away when we arrived. That was great bonus! All the staff are friendly and Mrg's Todd and Chadd were awesome for help when needed. We had been to the Imperial in the past and knew the perfect location it was in thus our return. It was our anniversary and that was the choice to rent the penthouse for something different!  The condo is renovated and has everything one needs with full kitchen and large lanai. I missed having another loveseat or couch to stretch out on so we ended up bringing a lounge chair from the pool area and putting it on the lanai. It was great to lie out and enjoy the view or just enjoy the morning sun before we hit the beach or shops. This unit being next to the pool has a door from the lanai to the pool however after setting the alarms off a couple times we chose to just use the regular pool entrance. It drew too much attention to us! (The alarms were to be turned off during pool hours) My husband used the gym daily and enjoyed that option. We did not use the hottub or sauna. Being next to an event venue is abit different however in saying that there was little noise and they were done early. It catered to mostly weddings while we were there and at no time was it open to the public which I had hoped. I did talk to crew while they were prepping for another event and was able to tour this beautiful venue. This venue is private and totally separate from the hotel itself. (OceansuiteWaikiki.com) He did state that October was completely booked for events and that we had missed out on the use of it being an open lounge to the public however November is a slow month and therefore it will be available then. It is very nice and beautiful to sit and enjoy the sunset with drink in hand. We were envious of the bar when we passed by as it was so close!!!The pool is as described on the 27th floor and it is windy however this time we stayed it did not seem to be as windy. We actually welcomed the breeze as it was a nice coolant in the heat. We have never been in October before so perhaps it is warmer than our usual trips in March/April. The pool has no ambiance, it is a basic pool on a rooftop. BTW there are towel chair covers for the lounge chairs and we only found out by commenting on them with other guests and they informed us they are available through housekeeping. That is not mentioned anywhere in the info packet. They are lovely and thick and much more comfortable than the regular pool towels. It would have been nice to have them in our condo at the time of arrival. This condo has its own wireless which was wonderful for me as I had my BB and my little laptop. I had difficulty initially accessing the wireless however after some help from Mgr Chad we worked it out. There was no cable hook up to be found and in speaking to Cindy the property manager it appears it may have "walked:" Internet is available for a fee (daily rate or weekly rate) in the owner's lounge. In comparison to other hotels in the area the price is pretty good although in talking to some owners they were disappointed with the additional fee. In the past when we rented from an owner the internet was free and those computers were always busy. This time there was nobody on the computers when we were there to enjoy the ocean view from the lanai up there. It is beautiful for sunset pictures! As also mentioned there is a Denny's restaurant connected to the Imperial and it was great for a basic breakfast after we did our beach walks. ABC is also right there and in the midst of an expansion. You will find that each ABC store is different and caters to the needs of the customers being served in each particular location of the store. Dont assume they are all the same as each one has individual differences and therefore they are all fun to peruse for that extra snack/drink/gift. There are restaurants galore surrounding the Imperial, Roy's, Ruth Chris Steakhouse, PF Changs to mention a few. Across the street is the Outrigger Reef which houses the Shorebird restaurant and the Ocean House restaurant. Both have great food and early bird dinner choices and on the oceanfront! We were in both places for Happy Hour drinks and early bird meals and enjoyed everything. The mac nut crusted mahimahi at the Ocean House was delicious!!! My husband enjoyed the early bird steak dinner that he can BBQ at the Shorebird! The Cheesecake Facory is a couple blocks down the street but be prepared for a long wait if you are going there for dinner. California Pizza Kitchen is nearby as well and they have great menu choices. This long strip is a mecca of great food choices and shopping! We have not been to Waikiki for 4 years and noticed a significant increase in shopping amenities if you like shopping. I liken it to the Vegas strip however no beach in Vegas! It is full of life and very busy. It was a great time and though it is city noisy the condo closed out all the noise when the doors closed. We did use the AC for the nights and that kept it comfortable for sleeping. We really enjoyed this vacation and the venue. We would certainly come back again! Thanx to Cindy for her help in the rental accomodation and to all the staff at the Imperial. Everyone was great and all very helpful.

We stayed here for 12 nights. First in a studio and then a 2 bdr apartment. Both rooms were fine but tired. The 2 bdr definitely in need of a renovation. The swimming pool is great but it is windy on the 27 th floor. The owners lounge has great views, computers & lots of comfy chairs. The imperial has broadband at a price but no wifi. The bar on 27th floor is open to public on some nights & is a must do for the view & cocktails. Staff were very good re any issues. Denny's & an ABC store are on the bottom floor. Some rooms can be quite noisy with the trucks coming to the hotels in early hours of the morning. The beach straight in front of the Outrigger isn't great but go to the next bay on your left or walk a bit further on the right for a lovely beach. Plenty of shops & places to eat right beside the Imperial.
user_name:
Jocelyn O
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: I first stayed here years ago because it was the only thing I could afford when I was very young and broke. Now I go to Hawaii once a year or so, sometimes more, and still always stay at the Imperial for at least a part of my trip because the value is tremendous - I have paid as little as $100/night.The hotel is ugly. Not gross, just ugly. Some rooms have weird blue carpet, pink toilets, dishwashers from maybe the early 80s, wicker furniture. The rooms vary - some are atrocious, some are quite a bit nicer. There is a small pool on the windy rooftop rather than a lovely pool with lounge chairs by the beach. But it is clean, the rooms are very spacious, there are a lot of suite options, the location is fantastic, some of the views are great and the prices are amazing. I don't typically spend much time in my hotel when I'm on Oahu so why bother with a more expensive place? The staff is pretty remarkable as well. Check in is always very slow - I have no idea why - but the valets are great and so helpful. But what impressed me most happened in December of 2008 when all of Oahu had a blackout. The Imperial staff was in the lobby handing out flashlights and radios and had an elevator operator to bring us up to our rooms. They were just wonderful.It's not romantic or beautiful or stylish. But you can't find a better deal anywhere.

We stayed here from Sept 17th through Sept 24th on the 20th floor it is the time share of a friend. I thought that the room was fine a little small, but sofa sleeper was horrible my husband and i switched from the murphy bed to just sleeping on the couch everynite. It is very close to the beach and the central pick up for activities is just behind the resort. Dennys and the ABC are right there so any small items you might need you can get there(but expensive).

We stayed at the Imperial in August as a timeshare. We were in a one bedroom with 2 bathrooms and a kitchen. The rooms itself was clean, clean, clean! It was a bit old but certainly comfortable.The location was really good, just behind the Halekulani and the Outrigger Reef. An ABC store located in the hotel as was a Denny's. Just across the street was Beachwalk which was very handy. Our room featured was a corner unit with tons of huge windows with a panoramix view of the ocean. Watching the sunset from this location was breathtaking. My kids loved the one elevator that had glass to the outside so they could look out. The pool on the top floor was a good size and was nice and warm. We swam in it on the days that the jellyfish were in the ocean. The service was exceptational, they were attentive and always followed up with us. I would stay here again if the chance presented itself.

My wife and I rented a two-bedroom time-share at the Imperial, and our needs were more than adequately met. The Imperial is not a new hotel, and it does not have a plethora of amenities; however, it is certainly fine for a home base from which to explore other parts of the Island. It's a block from the beach, convenient to restaurants and shopping, and relatively easy to find by car or public transportation.With the exception of a rather odd-sized bathroom (one of two in the unit), there is plenty of room for 4-5 individuals. There is also a pool on the roof - we found that a peaceful respite from the activity at Waikiki beach. There is an ABC store adjacent to the hotel, and that was a convenient place to get morning coffee and supplies.We would return to the Imperial. It's not the most luxurious place on the island, but it was just fine as a base of operations.

All in-all the Imperial Waikiki was a good find. It was cheap, clean-enough and in a central location. Because of the size of the unit & mini-kitchen, I wouldn't suggest having more than 4 adults in a 2 bedroom unit or stay for a long period of time. A little more about our stay; A total of 6 adults decided to catch a last minute flight to Oahu to see Pearl Harbor after spending 6 days on the Big Island. We booked one night (Sept 2011) in a HALA SUITE 2 bedroom, 2 bath unit directly with the Imperial Waikiki, at $210 per night. We didn't have high expectations of the Imperial after reading other reviews, but we chose this hotel because it was in a good location, cheap, knowing we would only sleep & shower here. Driving to the Imperial was a bit of an adventure, the hotel is situated in the city near shopping so lots of people walking, tour buses & one-way streets to navigate around. After finding the hotel, we handed the keys to the busy valet attendant (parking in the garage is $25 per day charged to the room). Hotel check-in was friendly & quick, our luggage was delivered to our room within minutes by a friendly employee. Our room was very basic, small, outdated (80s) and "fairly-clean"....it definitely needed a good scrubbing. The kitchen area is NOT really a full-size kitchen as they indicate on the website however it had the basics: a mini-fridge, a really old full size stove/micro combo, coffee maker & almost no counter space....you wouldn't be able to easily cook a meal. Also, we were on the 9th floor and could hear the noise of the street (honking ect). The noise wasn't bothersome to us, but could be if you are sensitive to sound or are a light sleeper.After passing our bedbug/rodent inspection we all quickly showered (The bathrooms were tight, but not as tight as in europe and water was nice & hot) and were out exploring Waikiki within 30 minutes of our arrival. In the downstairs lobby there is a cheap ABC Store, a couple of cheap souvenir/clothing stores. Directly across the street from the Imperial there is the Embassy Suites & Outrigger hotels and down the street there were lots of high-end chain stores, Fendi, Cartier and chain restaurants including PF Chang, Starbucks, etcFor dinner, we ended up at the Shore Bird restaurant at the Outrigger overlooking the beach & Diamond Head. Drinks were nice and strong & the staff was friendly. We watched the sunset while eating a large salad buffet and steaks we were able to grill ourselves! After dinner we stepped onto the beach to watch the fireworks before returning to our room. The linens were crisp and beds comfortable-enough. The next morning we were up early & headed downstairs to Denny's. Sometimes Denny's is questionably, but the food here was good, coffee fresh and staff was attentive & friendly. Personally, I do not plan to return to the Imperial, or Waikiki at all. It was crowded & had the hustle-n- bustle of a big tourist city...... ...the peacefulness, beauty & tranquility of the other Hawaiian islands is sooo much better!

A little bit dated but really clean and we had a one bedroom unit which had a separate lounge which was great, we had a side view through the Halekulani to the water, heaps of towels rubbish taken daily. The pool is just ok it was too warm for us but who cares the walkway to the beach is just out the back of the hotel providing excellent swimming and their are loads of restaurants in easy walking distant you are right in the midst of everything. Excellent value for money.

Excellent place with pool on roof (27th floor). Location is 100 yard walk to beach. Halekulani is between Imperial & beach. Denny's on ground floor for nice breakfast. Ray's across street is fine dining with open bar to street. ABC store on ground floor too. Convenient but pricey. Plenty of shopping on Lewers St. Starbucks in two directions: one diagonally across in Outrigger front area; the other a block & half up Lewers, same side as Imperial. Both Halekulani & Outrigger have fine dining & drinks possibilities. Room was small but adequate. Murphy bed & sofa. Gym on 3rd floor. Great for one or two. Also have largercrooms in building. No complaints for price. Good value. Considering the price of surrounding hotels, it is a bargain.

My husband and I wanted to find a hotel that was near the beach, reasonable rates and comfortable. Well, this hotel was cheap that's for sure, and next to the beach, but that's pretty much all it was. I would have to say you get what you pay for here! The first few nights were hot in the hotel because the whole air conditioning system was off. It did come back on after a few days, but it was still too warm. Then they decided to do some plumbing work and had the water shut off all night for a couple nights. It finally came on around 8:30am so we could shower, but it didn't come on when they said it would around 7am. Also later on in the week, in the middle of the night, I would say 12am to around 3am, there was strong pounding sounds coming from the inside of the walls. We called and complained and they said that they were still working on the plumbing and doing then. What? Who works on plumbing pounding on pipes all night long when people are trying to sleep? So anyway, it was cheap and near the beach, but really not cheap enough for all we had to deal with. People were friendly though.

This isthe second time we have stayed here with a timeshare swap via RCI. We had a 2 bedroom this time and the size was ok, the resort is of the best placed in the area and the owners lounge or club 26 as some members call it is without doubt the best around the view is one of Waikiki's best straight out to the ocean. The rooms are a getting tired and in need of an upgrade overall though for a timeshare swap this is still ne of the best and we would come again if we could get a swap

Actually did not stay at the Imperial, but usually visit Hawaii annually. This year we stayed at the Outrigger Reef just across the street from the Imperial, which was great and will write a great review for and highly recommend. However, the worst part of our 10 day vacation happened at the Imperial. We rented our car for touring Oahu and stopped at the ABC Store located at the Imperial.
