I really thought the drive in front of the ABC was for ABC customers and did not see any sign posted saying for hotel customer parking only and did not realize there was the valet at the end of the drive. I parked the car in front of the ABC and our friend went inside to get a bag of ice and I got out and went to the trunk and get the chest ready for the ice. As soon as I opened the trunk, the young Imperial Valet came to me and told me to move the car. I said "okay, just give me a second here." He yelled, "Move the car now!" I had drink bottles out and started trying to get them together. I said, "okay," but he continue yelling "move the car now!"Of all my trips to Hawaii, I have never been treated so rudely. On every island, I have also been treated as a special guest by everyone. This is the first time anyone has ever been so rude. I made a mistake by parking in the wrong place. I did not do it intentionally. I did not leave the car. I will never stay at the Imperial because of this.

I've never had a problem with this place. My in-laws have a timeshare here and let us use it on occasion. It's in the heart of everything, shopping, dining, entertainment and the beach is a block away. The staff are always friendly and helpful. There is on-site parking for $20 and if you need a cab they can get one for you within a matter of minutes. The activitiy center has been shut down and will be turned into a deli for the ABC Store. The furniture and artwork are a little outdated but so what. The only complaint I have, and it's really not a big deal, is the bathroom is pretty small. The pool on the 27th floor is nice, they moved the hot tub to the 3rd floor, the exercise room and sauna are on the 3rd floor also. We've always enjoyed the Imperial and will continue to stay here.

My first impression was a bit underwhelmed, but once I overcame being in a city which means crowds and noise anyway, it's actually a nice place to be. The gym is really well set up. The room itself is just OK, but the location is phenomenal. I'd stay here again, and would recommend it.

This is the best kept secret in Waikiki. Located right behind the Halekulani on Ocean Walk, there is no better locaton. Many rooms have ocean views and are appoint well with kitchenettes and multiple flat screen TVs and a DVD player. The furnishings are a little dated and the pictures in the room are faded (which might subconscuiously give you a cheesy feeling). Nevertheless, this place is worth every penny paid. It is a timeshare so it won;t have daily maid service. However, a short trip in the elevator and you can exchange your towels and linens twice a day if you wish. There's an ABC store right downstairs so you can get food or drink any time from 6am to 11pm. There's also a Denny's, Roy's, PF Changs and Subway within spitting distance. One drawback is that they charge for WiFi (wired) in the room.

We stayed at the Imperial b/c we used a timeshare exchange. Compared to most of the other hotels in the area, it was not a luxury hotel. However, it had everything we needed for a perfect vacation for us. The location was excellent. Short walk to the beach, restaurants, shopping, and public transportation. Although I have to say that the part of the beach that is less than a 5 minute walk away is small and unimpressive. To get to the beautiful part of Waikiki Beach, it's about a 10 or 15 minute walk along the Beachwalk. It's a very pleasant walk on the beach and well worth it.We had a 1 bedroom Banyan suite which met our needs. It had a pull out murphy bed as well as a sofa bed in the living room and a kitchen and a balcony. The bedroom was small and the bathroom needed updating, but it was fine for us. It was comfortable and quiet, and the staff was extremely friendly, helpful and efficient. Computers w/internet access is available in the Owner's Lounge on the 26th floor for a nominal fee. There was also and ABC store attached to the hotel which was very convenient. The location of the hotel, and the helpfulness of the staff more than made up for its shortcomings.

The hotel is not fancy, but is clean, good service and the location can't be better. If you are using the timeshare and have some down time be sure to check out the owner's lounge. The view is beautiful and it is a great place to just relax or hang out with friends.

Just returned from Waikiki.This Resort is a fabulous location, being on Lewers st.Rooms on the high floors(15th floor and above) have ocean views. The Banyan suite has a separate bedroom and the lounge has a murphy bed(pulls out from wall) and also a sofa couch/bed...a dining table and it has a kitchenette (but no oven-only a microwave)Easy walking to the shops of waikiki and only 2mins to the beach...Restaurants are good in that area as well..PF Changs, wonderful chinese.Arancinos, in Beachwalk..fantastic pastas and pizza.and a short walk to the Chessecake Factory, California Pizza Kitchen and Marguaritaville.Down side is that the beach is not very big there and not as clean as the other end of waikiki.....but it only takes 10mins to walk to the better water if you want to spend all day on the beach, its worth the walk.all in all..i loved it there...

I can’t believe the Imperial doesn’t get more love. I mean, it’s in a fabulous location, smack dab behind the luxurious Halekulani and only 1 short walk from the beach. It’s in the heart of Beach Walk which makes the location convenient for dining. We’d walk around the Outrigger Reef between the Army museum and be on the beach in less than 5 minutes, and the beach in front of Ft. DeRussy is wide and less crowded. The condo units are nothing fancy. I’ve rented various condos in various buildings over the years in Waikiki, and they all have been very similar, typically small and built in the 60’s or 70’s. Nothing different here. The Imperial is extremely clean and the kitchens are small but functional. You only get maid service once halfway through your stay, which is fine with us. Towels, including beach/pool towels are provided and you can swap your towels out with housekeeping for fresh ones every day if you want. Our trash was emptied quite a few times. There are laundry facilities on the 2nd floor and a fabulous owners’ lounge on the 26th floor. The view from the big balcony on the 26th floor is breathtaking – also a great spot to watch the Friday night fireworks.There are two rather new hot tubs on the 3rd floor as well as a small fitness center with cardio equipment, weights and mats. One could easily get a decent workout in while staying here. Off the lobby downstairs you’ll find an ABC store as well as a Denny’s, great for 1 a.m. rolling-in-from-the-beach-bar-munchies.Parking is $25/day (OUCH) or $100/wk for owners. WiFi is $15 per week.

Traded our time share week for the Imperial though RCI. We were impressed from arrival by the service and the friendliness of the greetings. We got a 17th floor one bedroom suite with a partial ocean view. Yes, the decor is dated, which hardly registers on the negative scale. The furnishings were more than adequate for a very comfortable stay. The suite had two flat panel televisions and dvd players, two baths and could accommodate six with a pullout couch and a murphy bed but it would be very crowded. The bed in the bedroom was reasonably comfortable. The hotel features wired internet for a fee, however I opted for service from a wireless hotspot from an adjacent hotel through Skywave for $24 for the week. Parking is valet for $25 a day but they offer a $100 for the week package. We enjoyed the pool deck, despite the fact that pool is small. All in all an excellent stay!

Bought a week here thru RCI because it had a kitchen & thought we could save on meals that way. Grocery stores were inconvenient to get to so ended up spending $$$ at the downstairs ABC for our breakfasts and beach picnics. For dinner we had fun trying new restaurants for their happy hours and specials. The hotel was very clean and beds comfortable. Street noise on the weekend but quiet during the rest of the week. Chairs and coolers could be rented inexpensively for the day or by the week. Internet was available for $3.00 per day. They had an awesome open air bar on the top floor that was available to the public when not being used for wedding receptions. What a jewel!! Highlight of our stay there. They would put out an inconspicuous sign near the elevators on the days it was open so we missed it the first couple times. The beach can be reached by walking across the street to the very short beach walkway. Used the fitness center every day. Nice pool on the top floor. Great location and good value.

We returned to the Imperial again this year after staying last year around the same time. This hotel is a little bit dated but has quite a charm about it as the people are very friendly and helpful. The location cannot be beaten and there are two fabulous restaurants just steps away in Roy's and also House Without a Key at the Halekulani. If you want good value for your dollar and not a high end hotel, this is definitely the place for you to go.

All in all a clean hotel with a helpful staff. we live in kaneohe and were celebrating my sons 6th birthday at d and b's, so we decided to make a weekend of it If i had a negative it would be no maid service on stays less then 3 days. The pool is heated at night. Being that it is on the roof that was nice. The lock on our sliding door was broken, we did not realize it until 11 pm at night. being we have young kids this was a problem. i spoke to the front desk and it was fixed right away.

This is my 2nd time to trade my time share for this hotel. Location is great! Next to Trumps tower, Halakulani, embassy suites, Dennys, Roys, great stores and coffee shops.. Staff is friendly, pool is nice ,beach next door, jacuzzis are good. The hotel itself is outdated, beds and pillows are not the most comfortable, but overall it's perfect for the location.. Don't stay here if you need high end amenities.. I would go back again.

Let me start by saying, I realize this is a time share property and many people who trade to stay here, do so because it's "Hawaii." That being said, I wouldn't suggest turning down Hawaii if the Imperial is the only chance you'll have to experience Waikiki. If not, and you have other alternatives, I would take a pass on this place.I stayed in the studio which may have led to my not-so-great experience. The 1,2,or 3 bedroom options are probably a little better. The studio did not have a bed. It only had a roll away (which was probably from the 70's and completely uncomfortable) and this "thing" that came down from the wall that they call a bed. It's probably a full size bed type structure which was also extremely uncomfortable. That being said, I did not sleep very well during my stay. In fact, 1 night during my stay, I went on priceline and paid for a hotel room just so I could get a normal night of sleep.Some of the pro's of the property: the staff is good and the location is good (pretty central to everything in Waikiki) Con's: it's an aging property and it shows, towels (bathroom and beach) were disgusting, uncomfortable beds, cleaning service only once per week, and dirty furniture.When it comes to travel, everyone has varying opinions and I realize that. What I would suggest to anyone who reads this is: ask yourself "have I ever stayed at a luxury hotel like four seasons, ritz, JW, etc?" If you have, don't stay at the Imperial. You will be completely let down. If luxury brands aren't your thing, and your used to staying at days inn and motel 6, then this place won't be so bad.Finally, the valet guys were great and were probably the highlight of my stay.

Well check in started not so good with walking up and gentleman working the desk just says " do you have a reservation" and I stated yes and my name, he said " give me your credit card". I would think a more curteuos gesture such as hello would have been nice.The rest went better for another co-worker came out to help with my friends and his attitude changed for the better with co-worker there.We had a one bedroom suite and a little outdated but very comfortable with a bit of a ocean view but no complaints on that end. Staff was very good with towel exchange and emptied garbage daily. Not having room done every day was not a problem for we did not spend much time in it.Location is perfect, period.The price of food is very expensive around that area but found some very resonable places of the beaten track such as a full breakfast for $5.00 and steak and Alaska crab for $20.00.The Denny's in the hotel had great staff and very good food and price.I shall stay here again and recommend this venue.I rented chairs and umbrella on the beach for $30. a day and used thier facilties which is worth it for you have it for the whole day and if you book next day it is only $25.We rented a car which I recommend for it rained a few days and we did our travelling then.
just back from 7 days at imperial hawaii vacation club arrived early room was ready and clean staff were just great location is realy good we hope they will have us back soon

I stayed in a 19th floor KOA (1bdrm, 2 bath) oceanview unit on a timeshare exchange (specifically an Interval International Get-away, which made it a steal of a deal) So this review reflectsI stayed in a 19th floor KOA (1bdrm, 2 bath) oceanview unit on a timeshare exchange strictly the timeshare unit not the hotel rooms. The location is fantastic, right across the street from the Halekulani, Beachwalk and Roy's restaurant and close to the beach. The building and my KOA unit were definitely older but clean. The bellmen are very friendly and helpful. A word of caution if the availability of the gym is a big issue for you: 1 of the 2 recumbent bikes was broken on the day I arrived, and by the 4th day they were both broken. So that made 3 of their 7 pieces of gym equipment broken with an unknown fix date. ("needed parts from the mainland") Do your own research on trip advisor re: activities before you book through their activities director. I went to the Paradise Cove luau with other guests at The Imperial and we thought it was a joke; do not assume the activity director is steering you to the best vendor and not just one that earns more commission. She never even asked me for any details when I complained about the luau, which leads me to believe she already knows about all the complaints. If you book the circle island tour make sure you know where the stops are and for how long. Normally the advantage of taking a smaller tour (van with about 12 people) is that you visit less of the touristy sites. However our tour parked us at Kualoa Ranch in their restaurant/gift shop for 1 hr yet planned only a drive-thru in Haleiwa (a much better stop for food and shops) and Waimea Bay. To David's credit he did stop for me in Haleiwa so I could get a shave ice at Matsumoda's since the waiting line was short, and at Waimea Bay so the Australian couple could get a picture for their grandson.

We were on Oahu for a football game between my alma mater and the University of Hawaii. I stayed here on a timeshare exchange basis so I can't speak to their rates. It is what I consider a very typical Waikiki hotel--somewhat dated but who really cares because you're never in your room. The location was excellent--a block away from the beach and a block from Kalakaua on Lewers. The biggest drawback by far was the comfort of the bed and pillows. I found the matress to be very soft and the pillows were too voluminous for my taste. On Friday night a group of immature young men checked into the room directly upstairs from us. They partied like they were 14 years old and their parents had left them alone for the first time. In addtion to the noise problems, they were smoking in their non-smoking room and the smoke was finding its way into our room through the duct work. Hotel management evicted them or relocated them at 5am Sunday morning after losing two night's sleep and our fourth complaint. Management might have acted quicker, but I can't fault them for the actions of the young men.I thought the staff was friendly like almost everyone in Hawai'i; although, our interaction with them was very limited as were either in our room or off property.My wife liked the surf board storage offered by the property. If you're looking a basic room with a great location in Waikiki you would probably have trouble doing better than this place.

I have been an owner at the Imperial since 1985 and I wouldn't trade it for any other location. Yes, it is old, but it has been kept in good condition, with lots of up-grading done in recent years. I know the pool deck is not posh or even upscale, but I'm not interested in pool activities-I go to Waikiki to enjoy the Hawaiian beach & views. Yes, some of the units on lower floors are small and little view-but we don't spend time in the rooms except to eat, sleep, clean-up, eat in when we want to just relax, change clothes, etc. Why pay hundreds more for a posh hotel when you don't use it any more that? The location is great-a short walk across the street to Waikiki Beach with a beautiful view of Diamond Head, Outrigger Hotel with several great eateries and entertainment; & entertainment at the Halekulani right on the beach is very professional & Hawaiian. A nice walk along Kalakaua Blvd takes you to shops, restaurants, more beaches, the zoo, a park with lots of activities, shows, etc..The staff at the Imperial can assist in car rentals, tours, shows, luaus at discount prices; they'll assist in giving info on cultural activities in the city as well as Waikiki area; and the convenience ABC store is handy as is Denny's downstairs. There's also laundry facilities, surfing lessons/boards available. I would recommend the Imperial for families, singles, and couples because it is in a great location, has affordable prices and a very happy, knowledgeable staff willing to help day & night. They'll go the extra mile for you if it is possible for them the help make your vacation a happy memory.

Everything you needed was there. The memory foam murphy bed was extremely comfortable. The a.c. was great and the kitchen and bathroom were adequately supplied. The elevators are slow and the cards needed to operate them and the room were finicky but being a 2 minute walk from the beach was excellent.We enjoyed the owner's lounge and the internet access was useful. Staff was friendly and prompt.

I must stay i was very leery about staying at this hotel after reading the reviews. My sister-in-law was in charge of securing our lodging accommodations, and she selected the Imperial Hawaii Resort. I was not comfortable about staying after reading all the negative reviews. As a back up, i booked a room at the Turtle Bay Resort. Well... to my surprise the Imperial was lovely. Nothing like the reviews stated. I immediately checked out of Turtle Bay and stayed with my family at the Imperial Hawaii Resort. Not a luxury hotel, but certainly not a motel (as some of the reviews implied). Awesome location. A short walk to the beach, and shopping (directly across the street from the Embassy Suites). Simply a nice hotel. We stayed on the 25th floor and our room was great. Sofa bed not too comfortable, but which sofa bed is.. The murphy pull out is very comfortable. Some complained about the noise... What noise? I didn't hear a thing. Yes.. an few delivery trucks, but it certainly didn't stop me from sleeping. I would certainly recommend this property. Oh... did i mention I work in the hotel industry. Keep in mind; it is very difficult to please service industry people because we expect so much. After all, we're constantly going over and above to exceed our own guest's expectations, and we expect others to do the same. This hotel was fine....

Travel dates: July 3-10/2010This was our second week in Oahu having spent the first week at Hilton Hawaiian Village (Hilton Grand Vacation – Lagoon tower, 1 bdrm). We got this unit through a timeshare exchange. We had low expectations of the unit since we knew it’s a much older building but with a great location. What we liked:Very convenient location for shopping, beach, food choices for a family. We went to Denny’s for breakfast and ABC store downstairs for snacks and supplies. We walked to the beach by Fort DeRussy or Waikiki area (in front of Sheraton very easily. Lots of high-end shops, souvenirs within 1-2 blocks. Royal Hawaiian Centre is also within 2 blocks. We went to the foodfair a few times to have noodles, Chinese, Korean and Hawaiian food. Because this is our second week in Waikiki, we decided to rent a car for a week. Parking at Imperial can only be done by valet. We paid $100 for the week. In general, staff were very friendly and always greeted/smiled at us. With the car, we bought groceries at Ala Moana and wet to other beaches (Ko Olina lagoons, Kailua, Waimea). If you are a timeshare owner, you have access to owner’s lounge on 26th floor. This is really spacious and had nice decor with a full kitchen, dining tables, lounge areas, and lanais. There is a full ocean view and good place to watch fireworks. This really came in handy on our last day after checking out to relax, eat take-out dinner and use the shower before our flight. We should have used this area more often since our unit was so small. If our unit was updated like the owner’s lounge, we would have enjoyed it more.What we didn’t liked:We were in unit 902 (1 bedroom) which faces east (view of Imperial Parc’s deck). This is a lousy view and we felt that we had no privacy. At any time, someone could walk onto the deck. We had to keep curtains in the bedroom closed most of the time. Sine this was over July 4, they were full and were not able to change our room. Mid week, they said a unit was available in a higher floor, but on the same side of the building. We would have to pay $50 cleaning fee if we wanted to move. We decided to stay. If you are booking at Imperial, you should request view of Fort deRussy side (west side). If you are high enough, you can see Hilton’s fireworks. If you end up on the Waikiki Parc side, request a room higher than 9th floor so you’re not so close to the building and right at their deck level.The unit itself is small. Living room contained a sofa and a separate Murphy bed. When the Murphy bed is out, the eating table and sofa/coffee table area is really cramped. The bedroom only had 1 night table and it was hard walking to the side of the bed facing the window. The bathroom was tiny as well. There is very little space to dry off and stand in front of the sink. Fixtures were all older. We thought we had a full kitchen but this unit did not have a stove/hot plate, only microwave, sink, fridge (with a freezer that did not work), coffee maker. This is fine for having breakfast, snacks and take-out food in our room. We have relatives who have timeshare in higher level units which have been updated and they have raved about this building. Our unit has obviously not been updated (but very clean) and really needed new curtains, bedding, carpet, bathroom fixtures. However, there is only so much you can do with the layout, which will always be small.Internet is not free. I think we paid $25 per week to use the wire connection in our room. Self-parking is not available, a bit inconvenient since you have to load and unload your car in the front drive way, in full view of everyone. Our son fell asleep in the car on the way back one day and we had to wake him up in the driveway (versus letting him sleep in the parking lot with one of us in the car).The small pool is on 27th floor rooftop is not inviting at all. After being at Hilton Hawaiian Village with their waterslides and large freeform pool, we didn’t want to even go into this pool. It was surrounded by walls with windows, so there isn’t much of a view. We spent most of our time at the beach so didn’t need the pool.

My family and I stayed from July 8-13th, 2010. My Husband and I were celebrating our 1st wedding anniversary. Had we looked to Trip Advisor to be the overall voice, or to a large degee, the final say of where we stayed, we would have missed the opportunity to save a dime, forcing us into a more expensive location, possbily ruining a wonderful week in Hawaii by spending more money on a room and forego the activities we had planned. Understandably, there are thousands who visit this time timeshare, and only a few hundred, who when dissatisfied over the slightest thing, are willing to write a review. Thankfully, we decided to be our own judge and are glad we took the steps to do so. The Imperial Resort is centrally located and situated in the perfect spot for all activities and shopping. We stayed in room 2508. Arguably, one of THEE most beautiful scenic rooms offered. The rooms are clean and not as small as the other reviews claim they are. Is the furniture outdated...not really. If you compared it to a 5star resort (SUCH AS TRUMP) possibly. It didn't have cascading water falls in the lobby and the rooms didn't offer large jacuzzi style bathtubs, but the feel I got when I entered the room, was simply...Hawaii. I didn't get the impression of being in a cheap hotel by far. It's valued high for the money you spend and comparable to being in any other resort in the area. Personally, I rate it to be a 4 1/4. Why the 1/4?? ...because my experience of timeshare resorts are slightly different in the fact that I'm used to having an "in room" laundry facility and at least "starter" coffee/tea packets offered in the room. Other than that, they accomodate everything I've seen stylish resorts to offer. They have in-room maid service conveniently offered on certain days and you have full access to xtra lines/towels during extended business hours. You have access to an in-house massage therapist and the spa area in very relaxing. I especially like the security they have with reaching your rooms, which means you need to meet your guest to take them to your floor. It takes a key card everytime you access the elevator...completely eliminating the possibility of children pushing buttons to see them light up. (Nice to know in a hotel that has 27 floors.) My husband is an Officer with the State of California and raved on that piece of security. His overall experience was so profound, he will be recommending this location to his friends and co-workers. (You would have to know my husband to know that's a BIG DEAL :) ) I suppose if you check the trip advisor for Trump Towers, they have bad reviews also...which goes to show, for the money, you just can't please everybody. I totally recommend you take the opportunity to see for yourself. In my opinion, You won't be dissappointed.

The Imperial Waikiki was the right location at the right price. 50 - 75 yards from the beach, just across the street. Our room was Penthouse II 2802. This room had the elevator shaft near the master bedroom and the elevator motors could wake you up at night if you are a light sleeper. The hotel has 28 floors, floors 16 - 28 facing south or west should have views to the beach. There is an ABC store and a Denny's attached. It is on Lewers street and is a very nicely renovated street with lots of new stores and foot traffic. It is clean, the lobby is simple similar to a holiday inn. It was priced comparable to hotels two blocks away from the beach, this one is very close to the beach so we got it and were not disappointed. If you pay to much, then you might be disappointed. Parking is 25/day.

The Halekulani & Sheraton Hotels are on the beach front. The Imperial just behind them, a small street and a public beach acess walk away. We went to the Halekoa(military hotel) parking garage to get our $16 a day, in and out priviledges, card key which allowed us into the Fort DeRussy self park, an easy walk past the Trump Tower and Embassy Suites to the Imperial building. We are not military. I did not want to pay the Imperial daily mandatory car parking valet fee. The short walk with luggage and kids not a problem.Entertainment Book Hawaii version has many coupons in the Waikiki area not just in the book but printable online coupons too. We dined at many 2 for 1's when we needed a break from dining in. Must print coupons before you leave home as there is no printer for guests to use, only for boarding passes at the front desk. Online access is $5.00/day from your room (own laptop) or in the owner's lounge.If you are a walker, Waikiki is doable with your own legs. My kids & I even walked to Ala Moana shopping center from here since dad had to go to work. If you are taking your car to hike Diamond Head crater parking fills fast so you need to go early. If you don't want to wait and have your car, take a stroll down the asphalt path to Diamond Head Beach (look where the surfers are carrying their boards) to pick up beach glass/shells. Nice view from the beach of the lighthouse. Rooms seem small but with kitchen, decent for Waikiki. Not a luxury hotel but better than budget, location a big plus. Flat screen tvs a bonus too.

I just got back from a week long stay at The Imperial. My husband and daughter (5 yrs) and I enjoyed it very much. The location is A+, right by the Halekulani and Outrigger Reef, across the street from Waikiki Beach. Yes, it is true, the property is aging, but we did not find it horrible at all. Everyone (staff and guests) were friendly and in a good mood. We stayed in a studio - Murphy bed (nice and firm mattress) with a futon - my daughter slept there. Our view was of Lewers Street - great for having a beer on the lanai and people watching (3rd floor). The room had a good size mini fridge, coffeemaker, toaster and microwave. All utensils included. Room was very clean. So was the bathroom. Just had a shower stall, but no big deal to us. Good closet space and nice flat screen TV with DVD player, so we brought some movies from home to watch. We are originally from NY, so yes it was noisy, only really bothered us in the very early AM when trucks were making their deliveries, but you want to be up early anyway and enjoy all that Hawaii has to offer. The convenience of the ABC shop downstairs is the best. We did find the Walmart on Oahu and bought our milk, bread, beer, chocolates, from there b/c ABC is pricey, but in a jiffy, it was convenient. And don't forget to try those coconut M&Ms...you will love them.Ok, the pool is cheesy and the hot tubs were not the coolest, but you are right on Waikiki Beach - just go there! GREAT views of Diamond Head - your pictures will totally rock.The Imperial is also right on Beachwalk, this new pedestrian friendly area with shops and places to eat - very nice with all of the lit tiki torches at night. You can also walk to the Royal Hawaiian Center - more shopping and people watching. Great location the Imperial - you are in the mix of Waikiki Beach.I recommend that you eat at Duke's at Outrigger on the Beach and try Eggs n Things on Saratoga Ave - THE BEST MACADAMIA NUT PANCAKES AND OMELET I have ever had in my entire life.All in all, I would stay at the Imperial again. It is not the fanciest or prettiest, but the location is fantastic and it was totally satisfactory for us.

This was a 20th anniversary celebration for my husband and I and if we had not read the reviews prior to our trip, we would have been very disappointed with the Imperial. We ended up staying at the Imperial because there were no other options available through our timeshare (Worldmark/RCI exchange).Check in was smooth. Our room was adequate. The bathtubs weren't very clean. The rest of the room seemed clean enough, but the room and furnishings are all very worn and aging. The location of the property was great. One block from the beach and right on the new beachwalk. We didn't open our balcony because of the street noise. As long as it was shut, the noise wasn't a problem other than the trash trucks waking us every morning. We weren't interested in sleeping in, so it was fine with us to use them as our alarm clock. We had a great week and the room didn't detract from the wonderful time we had. The on-site trip planner was helpful. We booked a couple of tours (island tour and snorkeling) with them. Don't know if we could have gotten better deals elsewhere, but weren't interested in shopping around. There is an ABC store right outside the lobby door. Not the cheapest prices I'm sure, but very convenient. We didn't rent a car, so can't address the parking. We used the bus most of the time.I can't whole-heartedly recommend the Imperial because of the dirty tubs and the very outdated/worn room.

We stayed there for a week, the room was dirty when we got there, but the staff took care of it quickly. The hotel is close to everything, but it is OUTDATED and the pool area is an eye sore as well as the 2 above ground jacuzzi's that they have. The room was nice, but again, very dirty. The staff was very nice. I would rate the hotel a 2.5. Parking was 26 a day along with a 6.00 resort fee, also they charge for internet usage.

We traded our week from our timeshare on Maui for a week at the Imperial. Rooms below floor 19 basically have no view at all (our original room had an alley and a cement wall for a view from the lanai). All of this after waiting 5 hours for our room to get ready. Front desk personnel tried to be helpful but could only do so much. They recommended we contact reservations and see if they could help. After being on hold for 20 minutes (she argued that it had only been 9 minutes) the only resolve was to upgrade at $30 a night! Rooms are dated. No stove and only a micro fridge. Internet is not wireless and costs $5 a day or $15 for the week. I would not trade my timeshare for this location again. Valet parking is $100 a week. It is close to many shops and restaurants. All things considered, I am not impressed with this property at all.

Location couldn't be better. The staff at front desk and housekeeping were good at making our stay personalized. Housekeeping changed out the cooking gear as it was not up to standards. A little trouble with the keys fitting. Tiny kitchenette in the palm unit so we asked for a big fridge for $10 per week. Stayed 3 weeks. The owners lounge if you can get access is on top floor had great sunset beach views and good place to bring your wine. Also, didn't have to bring my lap top.

Location, location, location. The beach and eateries are a stone's throw away, which is an important factor for me. This hotel is not the Ritz, nor did I expect it to be, but it was a great value. I traded my week with RCI and stayed at this hotel, room 2001. Yes, it was small and cozy, but clean and comfortable for me. I had a lanai with a partial view of the ocean. I enjoyed the large, flat screen TV in-room. The 26th floor owner's lounge, was a delight; there were unobstructed views with a wrap around lanai for amazing sunrises and sunsets. Conveniently, there were computers on the 26th floor too. I especially liked the 2 hot tubs and sauna on the 3rd floor. They were very relaxing. There was also a small fitness center, but didn't use it.The staff was so accommodating and helpful. They make this place shine. Mahalo nui loa!In short, I was pleasantly suprised by my RCI exchange and am happy to have stayed at the Imperial Waikiki.
user_name:
aliehssunday
New York City, New York

review_body: The rooms are small, dirty uncomfortable. The walls are peeling, the carpets are dirty. Overall the room is not what I expected, I will never recomend or comeback this hotel.

I am torn about this hotel, I LOVED the staff, but wasn't impressed with the room. The room has a "full" kitchen but with a mini fridge and NO freezer ?!?! HUH ?? How can you call it a full kitchen if the most important appliance isn't fully there ?? The bathrooms were tiny, no counter space, no drawers and no room. You opened the door and it banged right into the shower bar....which I guess is good or it might've hit the tub. Also you have to pay for internet , where most other hotels are giving it for free. It was a good connection, though. Better than the other hotel we stayed at. The pool was very tiny, but on the roof which was cool. BUT the valet service was amazing!! Great Guys (and girls?). So prompt and on the ball. The other employees were polite and friendly, as well.

I really think this is a hidden gem! We were a military family moving from Oahu when we stayed at the hotel. I did alot of research to find a reasonably priced, clean hotel for my family to stay at. We found the staff to be extremely friendly and the rooms to be very clean. We had a one bedroom suite with a kitchenette. Our room didn't have a view, but we weren't in the room except for at night. The hotel has everything you need or is located near somewhere you can get it. Definitely look at this hotel, we absolutely loved it!

This was our first time to Hawaii and Oahu was are 3rd and final stop on our 3 week trip. We used Hawaiian airlines for our inter island flight and they are an efficient outfit. We got a rental car through Hertz which was a Camry. I brought my GPS so finding the resort was easy, but once I got familiar with the area I would get off at earlier exits due to traffic issues. There is only valet parking at the Imperial which was $20 a day for owner/exchangers. We exchanged here through Interval International. The Valets do a good job and are friendly and will help with luggage to your room.The check in was quick and easy. They mentioned what any extra fees would be . We were given room 1105. The 11th floor room had a little ocean view between two of the resorts near by from it's small balcony. This is a 1 bedroom Banyon which has a limited kitchen. The resort is older, but the condition of the room was good. It is a little cramped compared to the condo style resoorts we're use to, but more than a usual hotel room. Kitchen had a small fridge, convection/microwave oven, toaster, blender, utensils and settings. The bedroom had a queen bed, end tables, dresser, and a HD flatscreen TV with dvd player. The livingroom had both a pull out sofa and a queen murphybed. A larger HD flattscreen TV and dvd player was in the living room. It also had a dinning table, coffee table, and dresser. The access to the balcony is through the living room. It has 2 chairs and a mini table. The worst part of the room is the small bathroom. It is small for one person and a little dated. There is internet hook up in rooms $5 a day or $15 for the week. The room gets a full cleaning midweek and trash is emptied daily. We had no maintenence issues during the week.Being a high rise, 27 floors, the elevator wait can be long at times. On the 26th floor is the owners lounge which has several balconies with great views of Waikiki, computers with use fee, large HD TV, daily paper, full kitchen for use, and pool table. On the 27th floor is the rooftop pool with vending machines and ice maker.. The pool is small and there is a lounging area. The hot tub was taken out and being renevated which closed the pool for 2 days. The lobby area on the first floor has several shops and activities desk. There is a Dennys and ABC convenience store just outside the lobby area. The key to this resort is it's location. It's in the Beach Walk Mall area. There are restaurants and shops of all types within a 5 minute walk. Within a 15 min walk you'll pass just about every top designer's store. Waikiki is 5-10 min walk from the hotel. You only have to cross 1 street. It's on the quiet end of the beach. There are venders where umbrellas, loungers, paddle boats, and etc can be rented. I found their prices to be high. Waikiki is a nice beach, but bring water shoes as it's rocky once you get in. Do not bring purses or any valuables to the beach. While at Sunset Beach a couple near us had their purse stolen. To save money we ate light in the room for breakfast and would grab a sandwich and snacks at foodland on our way to any beaches. For dinners we stayed away from high end places. Nothing stood out nor was any place real bad. As far as the north shore shrimp trucks I first tried Fumi's after to long a wait in line at Romy's. Fumi's was very good. We finally tried Romy's when there was a short wait. It was mediocre. After finishing we were still hungry and went to Fumi's for much better shrimp and slightly cheaper. Lesson learned, don't always assume the place with the bigger line is better. This also was evident with shaved ice. The famed Matsumoto's had large lines daily while Aoki's next door had lines not even half the size. We felt Aoki's was a lot better than Matsumoto's. We had a great week but could have used a few more days to see all that we wanted. Wished we passed on Dole Plantation since it's just a tourist trap. We prefered the northshore over Waikiki. The traffic in Waikiki is a headache especially in the evenings. Even walking at night the streets are very congested especially around some street performers/venders. Check out was easy with no surprise charges. I rate the room a 3, resort 3, location 4. The Imperial is a good 3 star resort if your focus is location.

We spent two weeks at IW in late April 2009. I recommend this hotel for people who are just looking for a place to sleep and willing to venture out beyond the hotel for activities.You cannot find a better priced hotel in a better location. Two of the best restaurants in the islands are within steps (Roy's and La Mer). A huge new shopping center is practically attached to the hotel. You are surrounded by the Sheraton, Embassy Suites, Halekulani, and Royal Hawaiian. Beware of fees. At the time of check in, the internet was free in the Owner's Lounge. By the time we left, they had switched it to pay for $5 per day ($15 per week.) Tax is somewhere between $4-8 per day. Parking is $20-25 per day. This cost (for us at least) was completely worth it. You have to have a car to get to all the great little nooks and crannys of the island. And you simply must make a trip to the North Shore, making a car important.The rooms were clean and adequate. The maid service was very good. The kitchen was great (although it is quite a jaunt to a "real" grocery store, SafeWay.) Very few of the higher floor rooms were available due to maintenance, and almost no rooms have a view of the water. Do not waste your time and energy trying to push them to give you water view.Overall, it was a good value and clean.

We just finished a week at this resort. We exchanged our timeshare through Interval International for this resort. The Imperial is mostly a timeshare resort. However, some rooms are marketed through the Imperial website for individual nights. This distinction is important because it will directly effect the room that you receive. Timeshare guests get the best rooms. Our room was on the 24th floor. As previous reviewers have stated, you need to be on the 20th floor or higher to get a view of the beach. You will usually pay more for ocean views at resorts / hotels in Waikiki. So, we were exceedingly pleased with the view from our room. People who pay for their room by the night (non-timeshare guests) will not have a nice view from their rooms and should not expect one. Furthermore, as a timeshare property, there are certain housekeeping practices that take place, which are common to timeshare resorts. Rooms are cleaned once per week (even if you pay by the night) and if you stay less than 3 or 4 nights then your room may not be cleaned at all during your stay. Trash is emptied each day and dirty towels were replaced during our stay each day. From our room, I was able to pick up a free wireless signal for my laptop. Others may not be so lucky.This resort is not a 5-Star resort and does not market itself as such. It was built in the 1970s and has not undergone major renovations since then. However, small improvements have clearly taken place. Our unit had two LCD flat-screen TVs (one in the living room and one in the bed room), for example. The microwave was also new. Most of the other items in the unit (the carpeting, couch, chairs, stove, etc) were definitely more than 20 years old. Everything worked and was clean at check-in.The staff was very friendly. The valet parking is $20.00 per day ($25.00 per day if you not a timeshare guest). We thought this was a very good value. Our car was always brought to us within 2 minutes! If you just want to stay on the beach, then I would just take a shuttle from the airport. We did lots of sightseeing since this was our first time in Hawaii.As many people have stated in other reviews, the location is excellent. I would be happy to stay here again if I was exchanging my timeshare. I would not pay more than $150.00 per night, however, if I was paying cash. You can get much nicer (and newer) properties in the same area.

We found this hotel to be very dated. One of the three elevators was down for rehab for the entire length of our stay while at the resort (there are 26 floors) which made getting to our room take a long time as the two operating elevators were often too full. The room was small and never got vacuumed for the four nights we were there. Also, the pool was very small, and the rooms had no view. Plus, if you do want to use the internet, you either have to go to the 26th floor or to the 2nd floor to access it which is a little hassle. However, with these things being said, the location of the hotel is great as you are in the heart of the beachwalk. In addition to this, we found the service to be very good at the hotel as well. For instance, every night whenever we returned to the hotel, the lady at the front desk (Tiana Lakanaria) always welcomed us back by name which made our six-year-old daughter feel very special. Tiana provided great guest service as did the valets. I would not fault the staff for the short-comings of the hotel as they do provide the best in service that they can, and we found them to be very polite and helpful.

This is the perfect condo for the bargain hunter heading to Waikiki. We just returned from a week stay. Wea re a family of Five - 2 adults and 3 kids (15, 12 and 9). The best feature is the location - 1 block from the beach and in the heart of Waikiki shopping and dining! Lots of options for meals from Denny's to Ruth's Chris all in one block. Of course you can also buy food items at the ABC convienece store attached to the condo and cook in your room - very nice after a long day a the beach and not wanting to go out! Very reasonably proced condo - we had the one bedroom/2 bath and it was perfect for us. Do not expect any extra room for spreading out but we did not spend much time in the condo - mostly just slept there. The worst feature is the parking - $20/day for timeshare exchangers or $25/day for others and only valet allowed. That got old! No view from lowers floor but you can get all the views you want from the beach or Diamond Head. If you are looking for 5 star go elsewhere - if you are looking for a decent place to stay while saving your money for excursions, suveniors, meals out this is perfect. I would give it a 3 star. Clean - no bugs, no smells, nice place!

Okay, so this hotel is NOT the Embassy Suites, BUT it is a really good price for the location! The hotel is right across the street from Waikiki beach, you just have to walk through one hotel to get to the beach. The hotel room was clean & neat. At first when we walked in I did get alittle disappointed because we were staying for our honeymoon, but then I realized it was very clean & great price, etc. So if you are looking for a cushy luxorious room, this is NOT it. But, if you are just out all day doing activities & on the beach (which we were) then it's a great place to sleep at night! The location is also close to everything else, nightlife, shopping, restaurants. Right on the street of the beach walk. We stayed on the 5th floor, the only problem was there was some construction going on in the parking lot across the street, but honestly anywhere you go in Waikiki seems to be under construction:( That part is annoying.Most of the staff with just one exception was VERY nice, the bell men are all very nice.

We stayed at the Imperial in a Palm unit (1BR, 2Bath) through RCI exchange. We were on the 15th floor. Only owners are assigned to rooms above the 20th floor, which you need to see the ocean. The bedroom bed and the queen size Murphy bed were very comfortable. The bathrooms need updating. The location of this resort is exactly what we wanted. We could walk to everything in Waikiki. The beach is accross the street, shopping is all around, you can jump on the trolly. You don't need to worry about transportation.Denny's offers carryouts and they were very fast - we ordered carryouts for breakfast and ate them on our balcony. The ABC store has whatever you forgot or need.The owners lounge is beautiful and huge. There is not a hot tub and we did not use the pool. The laundry is on 2nd floor and has a balcony to sit and wait.The Timeshare presentation is not high pressure. Actually very good prices for the resales. We recvd a one day car rental for attending the presentation.

The positives:The location is amazing!!The computers with Internet access and owners lounge with pool table are great.Unfortunately, the carpet and room smelled moldy. Every time I went in the room I felt ill and felt better after I left. There was also no hot water for 2 days.After we finally realized that the hotel was literally making me sick, we booked a new hotel. Although we had paid for the week, we packed our bags and stayed at the Wyland. We were so appreciative to be in a clean hotel (the Wyland) with hot water!!!

Love this place, close to the beach, the staf tries to keep this place up as best they can. They seem to have problems with giving your room away though, we were suposed to be in the 24th floor room(great view) when we got there, they gave our room away to someone else, and gave us the room with the view of Dennys Resturant roof, When confronted about this they lied about what happend, nice place, Bad Management....... I accually am a time share owner with this place, I will be using Hawaiian Timeshare Exchange to tranfer to other places in the future....

I loved staying at the Imperial again, it's perfectly located and whilst it is a little dated, I didn't mind, I love sleeping on the pull down bed, and watching TRU TV til the wee hours with the sound of the ocean. My room was clean, and fresh. The maid service did a great job every fourth day.The front desk couldn't be more helpful and supportive to my needs.The lifts are being serviced, and this was a lttle inconvienent, but all in all I had another great stay at the Imperial.If you are wanting luxury and decedance - go somewhere else, the Imperial doesn't claim to provide this, it provides a great centre of Waikiki experience.Mahalo

Let me start off by saying we are not real fussy poeple but this hotel was quite a disappointment. The rooms were small, filthy rugs with outdated furniture. The bed was a murphy bed, which is a good idea for a small room but it was the most uncomfortable bed I have ever slept in, anywhere! The room was not the cleanest but did have a microwave and small frig and small bar frig. The elevators were not all functioning, they were updating the middle one, so the waits were a little long. The hot tub was not in service and the pool was a joke. The front desk was never helpful when asked for information. The only nice part of this hotel is the owners lounge and had we known it was there we would have enjoyed the sunset once or twice up there during our stay. It was nice that there was the lounge to use when out of the room and waiting for our plane. I do not have any photos to post since I would not want anyone to know that I had stayed in a place like this.

Stayed with a friend at the timeshare in a 1 bedroom. Small rooms with a murphy bed, microwave - the outdated mirror wall did not add to the size. The lanai looked at the back or roofs of the NICE hotels in the area.Construction of the elevators, NO hottub & a DIRTY pool area!!Denny's & an ABC store on the street level added convenience for our stay.For a sunset, go to DUKE'S. Eat outside & save on the cost of food.LOCATION, LOCATION is the ONLY thing going for the Imperial!Just remember - Waikiki is NOT the real Hawaii!

My wife and I booked 7 nights at the Imperial through our timeshare. Our room was a one-bedroom, two-bathroom suite on the second to top floor of the Imperial. We certainly couldn't complain about the size of the suite--it was spacious, and in addition to the bedroom and 2 baths, had a kitchenette (a trip to the market saved us some money on food), living room and dining room area. The room was relatively clean and the bed was comfortable. The furniture is defintely outdated and a bit tacky if you care about those things. We did not. We had a view of the ocean, which was partially obscured by a couple of other high-rise hotels in the area. The view was still pretty nice. Guests get access to the owners lounge which has internet access and there is a pool on the roof. The pool scene was definitely NOT happening and it was largely deserted. But since you're in Hawaii, why go to the rooftop pool, right? The hotel allows you to check out beach towels which was great.One complaint I have is that the housekeepers come to your room early. And in some instances, they kept knocking even though we had the Do Not Disturb sign up. Another complaint is that there is no parking structure or lot. It is all valet, which means you get charged a daily valet fee.Bottom Line: The Imperial is a decent stay (nothing special), but the best reason to stay here is that it really is surrounded by everything you want to see. Just one block from the beach, and two blocks from the strip. There are plenty of stores, restaurants, etc. to see within close walking distance. So based on location alone, I would be willing to stay at Imperial again.

There were 4 of us in a Banyan suite which had only 1 bathroom. As we were on holiday that didn't prove to be much of a problem. The pull-down bed was reportedly comfortable. We found the staff to be very helpful. The location is excellent. The room is a bit dated but I'm told a refurbishment is underway. The use of the free computers was very convenient.

We (Family of 4 including two girls aged 9 & 10) recently stayed at this fabulous location. A timeshare resort which is located one building from the beach. The amenties were great we had a 1 bedroom apartment whihc had ocean views from the balcony( side views). The staff were freindly and the condition of the property was excellent. this would have to be one of the best timeshare resorts we have stayed in.The apartment had a full kitchen and the owners lounge had the best view in Waikiki looking stratight out to the ocean with no buildings to interrupt the view.A two minute walk to the beach, shops close by, $1.00 to wash & dry clothes in the common laundry the list goes onThis is definatley a place we will come back to

Our room wasn't great 8th floor facing a building, the toilet leaked called 4 times each time they did come right away to try and fix it. There is plenty of room to fit 4, but basically you spend so little time in your room in Hawaii. The owners lounge was a plus, free internet and computers a great view and a full kitchen in case you wanted to make a meal and lots of space. The rerrace also was great. Would stay there again due to convience, We booked late so we weren't expecting much.

This was our fourth trip to Oahu, and the Imperial. We love this location! Now that the construction is done on Lewers street it is beautiful and has a lot more to offer as far as shopping and restuarants. The views are beautiful from the pool deck which is on the top floor. We stayed in a Palm (which is a room with a seperate bedroom and has two bathrooms and a kitchen) which was very clean. They came and got your garbage every day and replaced towels. It could use some updating in decor but everything was functional. You would want to be as high up as possible as this will improve your view of the city and ocean. It is just a short walk to the beach (one block) It is very close to the International Market and Waikiki beach where you can watch the surfers or take out a catamaran. So much to see and do! The Imperial also offers the services of a conceirge who will book excursions to the Polynesian Cultural Center in Laie and to various Luau's.

We got a reservation over Memorial day week as a timeshare exchange. I read in previous reviews that if you are a timeshare owner, you get better treatment. It doesnt hold true (at least for us). I went in with a positive attitude about this place and considered all the nice reviews posted on this site. I requested a high floor in advance and the lady I spoke to was very nice and said they'll do everything to try and accommodate our request. We were assigned a PALM unit on the 9th floor. I said to myself, well this isnt a high floor but I didnt say anything. My heart sank as soon as we opened the room. The room was not only very outdated, it smelled outdated too. Our room was on the back of the building which gave us a nice view of the back of the adjacent hotel and the parking lot next door. Needless to say, it was dark and gloomy. We immediately called the front desk to try and see if we can get a better room but the receptionist was not helpful. He told us that they are fully booked and that there is nothing they can do about it. They said to try and call again in the morning. I tried to not let it ruin our vacation so we immediately unpacked and started heading out to the beach. WHen we returned later in the evening and were getting ready for bed. I pulled out the murphy bed from the wall so my 5 year old can sleep on it. As soon as I did, the dust came flying out of the wall, when you peek in the space between where the bed was and the wall, it seemed like no one cleaned it for ages. The dust was very thick. Since we were so tired, we made our best to tough it out and get a good night rest. For the next couple of days, we pretty much just stayed out of the room, only to go back and sleep. On our third day, my husband went down to the front desk to see if they can change our room but the receptionist was again unrelenting, he said he cannot do anything. My husband asked if there's anyone he can talk to, it just so happened that the manager was walking by, he then explained the situation and he immediately resolved the problem. We got a KOA room on the 15th floor. I found it to be cleaner, brighter and much more roomier. It didn't matter to us that both showers didnt have enough hot water pressure (almost like a trickle) so we took semi cold showers until the hot water started running like normal again towards the end of our trip. Just as I was about to say, this place is not too bad, another incident happened. We came back to our room after spending time on the beach and found that the door was left wide open. It looked like someone fixed the beds but forgot to clean the rest of the place. The garbage was not picked up nor were our towels and toiletries re- stocked. They just made the beds and left. (Remember, if you're checking in using timeshare, you only get the room cleaned once a week). After checking the whole place, we found that nothing was missing (thankfully) but we called immediately and security was sent to our room and had our door re keyed. The hotel has apologized but it really just wasnt acceptable for us. The only perks I can agree to is that the location is very good. You're within walking distance of good restaurants and shops. Valet service was great and friendly, giving us good directions all the time. They have a good selection of DVD's in the lobby that you can rent for $3.00. ABC store is conveniently accessible downstairs. Other than this, I can't think of anything else that's nice about it. The hotel pool was small and looked like an oversized bath tub (about half the size of a normal pool and I'm not exaggerating). You're better off swimming in the warm, beautiful beaches. Hopefully, other travelers will have a much better experience (and better room) than what we had. Unfortunately, our experience is such that we probably won't come back here again unless they do some much needed work on their hotel.

May 10 2008We just returned home from a wonderful vacation in Hawaii (Oahu). We (4) of us, my husband ,our daughter ,her girlfriend and myself,staying at the Imperial Waikiki. Timeshare trade for the Hale unit, 2 bedroom 2 bath.I honestly will tell you what a great choice we made. The unit was on the 22nd floor with a wonderful view of the ocean from each room. If you don't happen to get a room with a view don't worry. They have an owners lounge (26th floor) which has everything. Offering a full kitchen for use, pool table, computers,a big screen television to enjoy . Lots of sofas and chairs for all. ....but also that fabulous view. We watched the fireworks go off Friday eve. over the Hilton Hawaiian Lagoon from the lounge. Also on the 27th floor is the pool and hot tub with great views also. We met timeshare owners of the Imperial owning for 30 years now. They return every year they said. 4 lovely elderly folks.This was the first year they recall the pool being kept heated and warm at 84 degrees. We never used the pool tho. with the beach a block away.We all enjoyed ourselves, the location is perfect! The girls (early 20's) partied every night til 4 am. at the clubs very close by. The Beachwalk is very upscale, fine dining a walk across the street, or other choices up the block. You'll have to stay there to appreciate the location without paying 5 star rates! The famous Pink Royal Hawaiian is 1 block up.We all enjoyed their Luau. Trumps new Tower (Condos) going up presently is a half block away. If that doesn't speak for itself on location.Oh save the car rental cost. Take a taxi from the airport. Just rent daily if needed, it's close by.. The cost to park over night at the Imperial is $25 a day. We only needed a car 2 days and rented daily, returning it back. Do drive up to Ko-Olina and the Lagoons available for public use. It's at the Marriotts Resort. Also enjoy driving the Island to North Shore.approx.( 3 hours.or less) Or call for a shuttle, as we did to get to the Arizona and Missouri. $12 ea.roundtrip.Hey a high 5 for all of us. We walked from the Imperial along Waikiki to Diamond Head. Then hiked up Diamond Head for it's incrediable view point!!! Of course we took the Bus back which you may take right outside the park. $2. each. Pick up a bus schedule at the hotel. Or walk. as we did. :o) Great exercise.in ending........The staff (all of them) excellent and so helpful. Thank you Tony (reservations manager) for such a great room, which just added to our enjoyed time there. My husband and I enjoyed many cocktails on our lania watching the Beackwalk and activity below. I rate this hotel at the top.We would definetly plan another stay there if on Oahu again.Carla........ from California

Lewers St. has undergone a major renovation with Trump moving in the area. Imperial of Waikiki is in the process of deciding what renovations are needed to remain in this improved area while still maintaining its affordability.That being said, if you don't expect class A accomodations, you will be happy. The rooms are small but clean. You must like the people you are travelling with. You will not be able to make a gourmet dinner in most of the rooms, as the kitchens are mostly a dorm fridge, microwave, coffeepot. Some have small stoves or oven. Fresh towels and linens are available but requires you to get them as room service is only provided on a limited basis as this is mostly a timeshare type hotel. But you can get almost anything you want with a trip to housekeeping.Some room views are excellent, and others are very disappointing. Waikiki in general is like this. There does not appear to have been any urban planning when the high rise hotels went up. Each hotel got progressively bigger the closer to the ocean causing most hotels to lose unobstructed views.Parking in Waikiki is going to cost you your first born child anywhere. The Imperial raised their daily fee to $25.00, plus it is valet parking and you will need to include the tips on top of this. All of this being said, there are some of the nicest people employed by the Imperial Of Waikiki. Kona in the travel department can get you tickets and transportation to everything, RJ and the bellhops go out of their way to remember you. The service counter personnel were extremely polite and knowledgeable.I have stayed at the Imperial many times and I have also stayed at other, more expensive hotels in Waikiki, but I keep coming back because of the staff.

My husband and I stayed at the Imperial for a week in April, 2008, and absolutely loved it. We knew ahead of time we were not getting a five-star hotel and did not expect too much. We were so very pleasantly surprised. We had a one-bedroom, one-bath unit on the 9th floor. No ocean view, but we knew that when we booked it. The condo was spotlessly clean, and modestly but comfortably furnished. All linens and kitchenware were in perfect condition and exactly as advertised. The building and grounds were well-maintained and the staff was wonderful. We had a full mid-week cleaning as well as daily trash and wet-towel removal. As we were there on an exchange basis, we had access to the owners' lounge with computers, big-screen tv, full kitchen, and three-sided decks with fantastic sun and views. The Imperial is absolutely right in the middle of everything in Waikiki and although we had a reserved a car, we found we didn't need it and took it back early. We could not have been happier with our accommodations and hope to return.

Our first visit to Hawaii/Honolulu and we had a blast! Mahalo everyone. Now the hotel, remember folks this hotel is 2 star... who stays in the room in Hawaii??? Not us. We slept well and were treated better than at any hotel on the mainland that is a 3 or 4 star. The staff was great, so friendly and helpful. Loved having the ABC store on the main level. Yes the decor is dated, but it was clean and well maintained, I understand that the owners are slowly redecorating each room as they go. As to the construction, and we were on that side, so what???? again we were out all day and most of the evening enjoying the beauty of the island. It was good to know that Honolulu is moving ahead. Having the beach 1/2 block away was awesome, as well the bars in the hotels along the beach we so much fun, we met some wonderful folks including some military officers who were a gas to spend the evening with Aloha friends. We will return and have recommended this hotel to the sister and her family since it's so affordable. Thank you to all the staff at the Imperial MAHALO and we will be back, hopefully this autumn(2008) and this time we'll be checking out the timeshare options. ALOHA

We stayed at this nice little hotel on Lewers street. Great service -we were allowed to check in early and had excellent service from the front desk and valet all week. They gave us great tips on restaruants and had even clipped coupons saving us a ton of money. Valet is extreemily promt almost too fast. We received every wake up call we asked for. The beds are comfy and it is nice to have a small kitchen and fridge. We stayed in a Palm unit with our 3 kids and felt the space was more than adequate and the extra bathroom makes a huge difference. Love the lanai's (Balcanies). We had 3 families staying in different units all traveling together and everyone had an excellent stay. Some units are more up to date than others but we spent most of our time at the various beaches and other activities out side the hotel-it's not the ritz, but it is great. It is a perfect base camp and we woke well rested every morning ready for adventure. The new shops and restaruants on Lewers street make this one of the best locations in waikiki. You have everything you need with in a few strides...literally. The beach is 3 minutes or less...enjoy all Waikiki has to offer from this perfect location! Nice pool and hot tub upstairs-the pool was a little chilly. Leave your beach towels at home you can check them out from the hotel...nice touch. Get with Kona for your island adventure activities she is the best! Small things like leaky shower nob easily overlooked.

This is a great place to stay! Spacious rooms and a friendly staff. The parking is a bit expensive at $25 a day but other than that everything was great. It is very close to the beach and to many restuarant, shops, etc.

The location for the Imperial was a definite plus, close to the beach, close to the stores and shops, and close to other key locations. The hotel facilities were quite comfortable and the staff had a very laid back attitude. They were more then willing to accomodate any needs we had. The tours offered were well worth it and not too costly. They have a cute little exercise room, but I found the pool area to be too small as well as the pool. It can get a bit cramped there. All in all, a nice and comfortable stay.

My boyfriend and I stayed at the Imperial at Waikiki in late June of 2006, using his sister's time share. We stayed in a one bedroom, two bathroom suite on the 19th floor with a spectacular view. The accomodations were a little outdated, but very clean. For the price and location though, you can't beat it (we paid $15 a day for valet car service and room taxes). The Imperial is right across the street from the beach! The furniture was reminiscent of "The Golden Girls" and the carpet was a bright green, but you're in Waikiki!... it's supposed to be tropical and cheesy. The kitchenette was well stocked and sufficient for 2-4 people. We went to the market and bought food and snacks for the week. The A/C worked well, and the water pressure in the bathrooms was good. The lanai was small, but sufficient with 2 chairs and small table and ashtray. The view was great! We could see the beautiful Halekulani across the street, and a patch of the ocean beyond.The staff was very friendly and helpful, especially the valets on the ground floor. We never waited more than 5 minutes for our car, and they were great with directions and maps. The elevators were in high demand, and we did wait a little while to get up to our room or down to the lobby, but nothing ridiculous.Basically, this was a great place for a nice laid-back vacation to Hawaii. Right near the beach and in close vicinity to shopping and dining, etc. We will be going back there in January 2008 and looking into buying a time share of our own.

Terrible Hotel! We stayed in the 2 bdrm. Hala "Suite" at the Imperial of Waikiki for 7 days. We wanted to check out the day we got there! Bathroom sinks were chipped/cracked, front bathroom shower never drained water, carpets dirty, furniture from the 70's, two double beds in master bedroom! We had to sleep in separate beds - my husband was bitten by bed bugs!!! The rooms are outdated, the staff were nice until we complained, then refused to put us in another room. Found out that 25 rooms were being "repaired"! A Motel 6 would have been nicer and more updated. We will NEVER stay there again and don't recommend anyone stay there for health reasons! The whole building needs to be renovated from the ground up.

Resort in great location to beach and shopping. Room was above average. Accomodtions were not comparable to property in Orlando but it was clean and served it's purpose. Staff were ALL friendly and helpful. Stayed in 1 bedroom 2 bath with Murphy bed and pullout couch. Guest said the Murphy was comfortable. Decent work out facility. Highly reccommend. Would stay again.

This was an alternative to the Fairfield property I reviewed earlier. It is also part of a timeshare program. If you overlook the dated decor, this place is very good. As you can see from the pictures, it had the Hawaiian floral printed cushions on white rattan. I was in a 1 bedroom, 2 bathroom unit.Pluses ~The shower pressure was great and there was always hot water. The kitchenette had a microwave, coffee maker, toaster, stove, and dishwasher. There was plenty of utensils, plates, pots, etc. There was a small but adequate lanai, an iron and board, and hairdryers in both bathrooms. The best thing was the pull-down bed. It was very comfortable and unlike those worn out sofa-sleepers.On the third floor was the fitness center and even a sauna. There were washers and dryers on the second floor, which also had a t.v. The pool was located on the 27th floor and there were beach towels available.The staff was very friendly and helpful. Simple requests were handled promptly and professionally.Minuses ~Elevators were a little slow at times. The AC seemed a little archaic, but adequate. I didn't like the gap underneath the door because warm air blew in. The only t.v. was in the living room. Overall, I enjoyed my stay. It wasn't as nice as the Fairfield property I stayed at last time. I spent most of my days exploring parts of Honolulu. I would stay here again because it's centrally located. There was not much construction noise while I was there, but they have not started on Trump tower yet, so that could change.

Rented a one bedroom for a week from a timeshare owner. Room was on the 18th floor facing west. We had ocean and city views and Embassy suites hotel across the street. For un-obstructive views try to get a room above the 19th floor.The greatest asset of the Imperial is its location. It is centrally located to all the wonderful shops and restuarants of Waikik and directly across the street to the beach via the Holukalani Hotel. Staff is friendly and very helpful. While some may complain about the parking being $15. Parking in Waikiki is very costly and I found it to be reasonable with in and out privleges. We stayed 7 nights and just rented a car for 4 days more than enough time to see the other parts of the Island. The room was comfortable and equiped with a micro wave, sink and small refrigerator. While a cooktop would have been more convinient. The setup met our needs. The rooms do need some decorative updating thought they are clean and well kept. There is one TV with dvd player in the living room and murphy bed. A TV in the rather small bedroom would have been nice. the living room and bedroom each have balconies. There is a game room and computers (also wi-fi for those that bring there lap tops) on the 26th floor The game room also has large balconies which command incredible ocean/city lights/and mountain views. It is ideal place for viewing the Hilton's Friday night fireworks. the pool and jacuzzi are on the 27th floor. While the pool is small the 360 degree views are impressive. Overall, we enjoyed our stay and would recommend the place.Strongly recommend the shore Bird cafe at the outriigger adjacent to the Halukulani Hotel. Has rgreat ocean front views and great night time entertainment. For take out I suggest CoCo Cove on Kalakaua Ave (between seaside avenue and Nohonani).

Though we'd heard, through a travel guide, that rooms below the 20th floor were blocked by another building and we would not have an ocean view--certain rooms from the 15th floor up (we were in 1603) do have the view because part of the obscuring building is only 3 stories high. Lucky us!This building is older and reminiscent of an all-suite hotel that was converted to time-share condiminiums. The unit (we had the one-bedroom Palm with 2 baths) was small--one could barely walk around the queen-sized bed but it was freshly painted with new carpeting. The kitchen appliances and cupboards were in need of updating but serviceable.We never used the rooftop pool, which was smallish and subject to a lot of wind.Staff was pleasant and helpful. When our coffeemaker would not activate at 5:00 a.m., a replacement was delivered within 20 minutes. The reception desk personnel were cordial, travel desk personnel were generally good--and in one case great, and the Housekeeping staff in the linen/supplies room were wonderful.Speaking of supplies, we always carry a "condo pack"--paper towels, toilet paper, salt and pepper, dish liquid, etc.--when staying in condos because we never know whether or how much of certain things will be supplied. At the Imperial, we never needed to dip into our personal supply because of the good initial supply and ability to replenish from the linen/supplies room.The location of the Imperial can't be beat! It is right next door to an ABC (convenience-type) store so most or all food stock is readily available. The new Beachwalk--stores and restaurants--is within a few feet, tour-bus pickup is close by, and it is a short walk to city buses. Of course the nearby beach (small) is within a short walk as are a lot of good restaurants, including those at the nearby Outrigger. A good walker can--in a two-mile stretch--get to great beaches, shopping, food, and transportation.We were happy to see a sign requesting guests to please use the ashtray on the lanai if they wanted to smoke. Evidently it worked because, contrary to my fears, we suffered through no smoke-related odors.The room itself was only average but the location and service brought my rating up to Above Average. No complaints from this veteran condo exchanger!

Oh the poor Imperial… While staying in Waikiki, I find that condominium buildings are more comfortable--and ultimately affordable-- than hotel rooms. The Imperial is conveniently located on Lewers Street in the heart of Waikiki and is a stone's throw from the beach. Lower units have no view, but upper units have ocean and territorial views. The interior of the building is quiet and secure, and there is a pleasant rooftop view pool. Most of the units that I have stayed in are dated but in modest/serviceable condition with small kitchenettes. The rooftop community lounge/tv/free computer/pool table/kitchen has a spectacular view. As of this writing (11/15/06) I would *not* recommend staying at the Imperial (or any other Lewers Street hotel) until late 2007 or 2008. There is *significant* construction and new hotel development in the area and it is noisy and dirty. After the neighboring Trump Hotel is complete, the neighborhood (and my rating) will improve significantly. In the past I have paid between $85-125/nt. You may find more information at the building's website.As always; I travel to Waikiki several times a year, I can advise that Waikiki is a nice tropical urban adventure. The city comes with the negatives of a big city, along with the overwhelming benefits of a beautiful beachfront resort. Generally, everything in Waikiki is “a little tired” although there have been continuous improvements in the last few years. If you are traveling solo, take Roberts Hawaii from the airport for $10 (no rsvr rqd).Two or more people, take a taxi from the airport to the hotel (should be under $30). In Waikiki, nearly everything is walking distance or a short shuttle/bus away. If you need a car for the day, you can rent one in Waikiki.

Location, Location, Location this hotel is in the heart of Waikiki. A few yards in any direction and you find the best of Waikiki from restaurants, shopping and beaches. The rooms aren’t the most up to date, but for the price a comfortable bed and a clear TV will do. The hotel staff is very friendly and knowledgeable.
