The excursion desk staff helped us make our trip a memorable one. So if you’re looking for a comfortable, pleasant and economical hotel choose The Imperial of Waikiki.

My young daughter and I booked the studio through my RCI timeshare. I was nervous because of the past reviews posted on this site. I did not experience any of the problems reported by other travelers. (I did observe one gentleman at the front desk complaining about a leaky fridge.) This is not one of RCI's best properties but it suited our needs. Yes, it could use updating but the unit was clean, the appliances worked, the linens were in good condition and the staff was very friendly and helpful. The bathroom especially could use a remodel, but again, it was clean. The owners lounge on the top floor was very nice - the lobby was nice too. I left my daughter's book of DVDs in the unit (over $300 worth) and the staff made arrangements to get them back to me. You can't beat the location - right in the middle of everything and very close to the beach. I would book a unit here again. Downsides: $15 daily parking fees, no wi-fi in the unit itself (had to go upstairs) and a very small pool.

I just returned from a 7 night visit to Hawaii. I bought a timeshare week from an owner who could not use it. I have stayed at several hotels around Waikiki. For the money, this is a great hotel. No, it is not a 4-5 star hotel as many other posters have indicated, but you are not paying those kinds of rates either- I would rate it as 3 stars. The rooms are dated & eventually need renovating in the near future. I was on the 15th floor facing Lewers St.. For the most part, the $460 million street renovation is done so the outside noise level is pretty much nil. The street is fabulous looking now. As far as I'm concerned, the room was clean, comfortable & much too my liking. Local calls are free. While I did not use the fully equipped kitchen except for the fridg, I thought it was very functional. The bed was firm & comfortable. There is TV with DVD player with a DVD rental plan in the lobby for only $3/day for 4 DVD's/day rental. Being a timeshare owners room, I was given full access to the owners lounge on the 26th floor. It had 4 desktop computers with full web access & unlimited wireless if you have your laptop with you, for free. It also has a pool table, big screen tv with several very comfortable black leather couches, full kitchen, & tables. But probably the best thing about it is the large balcony with an incredible ocean view. The front desk & valet staff were extemely friendly & helpful. The convenience of the ABC store & 24hr Denny's right outside the lobby is definitely a plus. Across the street the new Plaza has all the new high end eateries you can spend your money at if you dont want to use your kitchen. Location, location, location- you are only 100 yards away from the beach & in the thick of shopping. You are nestled amongst some of the most prominent & expensive hotels in Waikiki- Waikiki Sheraton, Halekulani, Royal Hawaiian paying much less. I consider myself pretty well traveled around the world & can tell you, for the money, it's hard to beat this hotel , all things considered. I was so impressed, I bought a week timeshare before I left. It's in escrow now. Just to give you an example of what a bargain it is, next door is the Fairfield timeshare hotel that was completely renovated inside & out is going for $21k to 41k versus Imperial hotel (exterior renovation only) @ $4k for a lifetime. If you are going to visit Waikiki every year & are half way interested in a timeshare program, I highly recommend you visit with Phil in the sales office in the lobby. You'll be glad you did. They don't have barkers standing outside their timeshare hotels trying to hook you in- they don't need it!

Our Imperial stay was March 6-13 2007. Room 405 had alot to be desired. The view was a green tarp with bird poop or a parking garage. I couldn't stand to open our curtains so I didn't. what a shame for I love Hawaii. Our bedroom was very small no tv but, the ac did work properly. Now the living room area med. size but the ac didn't work properly for our last 3 full days. The maintance worked on it but it only stayed on for about 2 hours and broke again. Our shower was very tiny and the bottom of the glass door broke the 2nd day and had to be repaired. Towels were fuffly and replaced when needed. Our mid week cleaning was so so and they didn't vac. the bedroom. Pool area was very lacking in any decor what so ever. Thank goodness the beach was close and shops. So I would say location was the best part of this hotel. Front desk staff was nice. Valet parking only -at 15.00 a day, and beach chairs to rent for 3.50. I would pick a different hotel to stay in on my next visit to Oahu.

We traded a week with Interval International. The stay was just above average. The hallways and rooms (22nd floor) smelled of cigarette smoke. It seems to move through the air conditioning. The rooms (studio) are in desperate need of upgrading. The bathrooms have cracked tile and are small. The valet service was agressive and poor. The only woman working at the valet counter was rude and agressive. The location was fantastic! It is probably in the best location in Waikiki. There is construction going on for the new beach walk. Try to book on the South Side of the location (not the Lewers Street side) as the noise starts early in the morning. The views are OK. The lanais have cheap plastic chairs and table. There is a very convenient ABC store in the lobby. Denny's is located right next door. The hotel is good for the gay travellers as it is only blocks from the best gay clubs in Waikiki.We would definately stay again but would be very specific about our request.

every 5 years, we attend the pearl harbor survivors reunion. we have stayed at the imperial in the past and it worked well for us in a 2 br, 2 ba suite. however, in the past 5 years, no apparent maintenance nor upgrades were done to the rooms and it is drastically needed. rooms should be much cleaner than this!the pull out bed was in such bad condition it had to be replaced with a regular bed to accommodate sleeping. two of the stove burners were out completely, the faucet could not be turned off to prevent constant dripping, the phone didn't work and daily maid service was non-existant. if we needed towels, soap, dishwasher detergent, etc, we had to go to housekeeping to get it ourselves. but the worst thing of all was the CONSTRUCTION NOISE LEVEL. impossible to sleep past 7am and believe it or not, they worked on sunday which meant 15 days of unbearable noise!!!the desk staff and concierge/valet staff was incredible but that hardly made up for the complete inconveniences.check your bill carefully. what should have been around $225 was more than double that amount and had already been charged to our credit card making it impossible to dispute the charges. until, or unless, improvements are made and charges are honest, we would not stay in this hotel again and would not recommend it to anyone.

I have been staying at The Imperial every summer since 1998 and wouldn't stay anywhere else; the location, friendly and courteous staff, very reasonable cost and great rooms and views are all important to me. A friend recommended it in '98 when my son was in the military there. Even though he is no longer there, I can't wait to return each year and enjoy everything Hawaiian. I highly recommend The Imperial!

we had a two bedroom "suite" - the internet made this place look much nicer than it is - construction all around though not the fault of the hotel, BUT, surcharges for EVERYTHING - they even tack on a 5$ per night charge, which "covers" your video rental - we never once took a dvd to watch or had any intention of it, but they charged us anyway! it was non-negotiable! - the hotel is old and really unimpressive, even to a basic hotel - i'm not a snooty traveller demanding the best of everything - but i don't see a lot of service-life with this place left - it either needs to be torn down, renovated, or re-priced to reflect it's below average standards - for the price we paid, we could have been enjoying an oceanfront

We booked the Imperial through RCI, our timeshare company. We own a crown resort near San Diego. Ours is new, clean, modern, has 2 pools, a gorgeous view, etc.....The Imperial reminded me of a hotel/motel facility from a roadtrip through the midwest in the early 1980's.My advice, dont go.Musty throughout the entire complex. The pool on the 27th floor had no atmosphere, was under construciton, small, and concrete, no plants, or anything to make it inviting, we spent 2 minutes checking it out, and did not return.The rooms were small, and the carpet old and worn and stained. We had an alley view with construction ongoing. The ants out on the patio eventually made it inside. The dorm sized refrigerator leaked the entire time and we soaked it up with towels on the floor. When we told housekeeping they said, "oh, yeah, they leak, just keep the towels there"HELLLLLLLOOOOOOOOOOO!!parking was 15.00$ a dayNot romantic, no pool to lounge around at, no fun atmoshpere to hang out in.Here are the positives:1. the hotel staff was friendly, but not that helpful with recommending restaurant info2. it was a 5 minute walk through construction to the beach with many close restaurants and bars to hang out at3. ABC store conveniently located on first floor just outside lobby.Thats it, nothing else good about the Imperial, spend a bit more and get some atmosphere and cleanliness!!

I stayed at the Imperial with my family in July 2005. After being a little apprehensive (I had heard bad things things about the Imperial, such as bugs, a lot of noise, unfriendly staff, and the rooms being dirty), when I got to the hotel, none of the things I mentioned were true. Well, except for construction noise, which just can't be helped. The rooms (I stayed in two -- one for a night as a hotel room and the other room I spent an entire week in as a timeshare) were quite small but they were clean. The staff was great. They were really helpful with all of my family's many, many questions that week and they were very friendly. The location wasn't bad. We didn't have to walk far to get to some restaurants and some shops. It is recommended not go out alone or even in groups of two after dark in the neighborhood, though we never heard of anything happening while we were there. I would recommend smaller families to stay at the Imperial (Unless a larger family got the biggest room). It isn't exactly the most romantic of places for honeymooning couples but if you don't mind that, then this is a great place for just about anyone because it's not expensive like most hotels. I really enjoyed my stay at the Imperial Waikiki.

Never again! The only thing positive that I can say about this hotel is that it is close to the beach. However many of the lanais are locked off for repairs and the loud work starts early in the morning with a construction worker staring you in the face. The rooms are stuffy, shabby and dirty. The beds are also very uncomfortable. Don't expect help from the management because their attitude is, if you don't like it go somewhere else. Which is just what you should do.

My family and I stayed at the Imperial over Christmas 2004/2005 and plan to return again this Christmas 2006. I was there with my husband and 4 children. The pull down beds made it possible for all of us to stay in one unit (Banyan Suite)i sitting room, 1 bathroom, 1 bedroom, mini kitchen (we had breakfast in our room most days). Yes it was a tight squeeze at bedtime but with the beds up during the day there was plenty of room to move around. The bathroom was clean and well stocked. We didn't spend much time in the room we were always out at the beach or exploring - who goes to Hawaii to sit in the room? We had a view of the ocean between two hotels and that was all we needed to check the weather and beach conditions. Our Teenagers loved all the activity in the city and we had a great time exploring the shops and restuarants. The beach was wonderful lots of people watching! great sunsets every night. We went to the northshore as well and loved the big waves and lack of crowds was a nice change. The hotel itself was clean, centrallly located and the right price for a family of 6! Our kids enjoyed the hot tub, the pool; looked fine we swam in the ocean though. We had no trouble with maid service or getting fresh towels whenever we needed them. The staff were always friendly and eager to help, we were always polite and friendly to them too!!! Christmas morning Santa even visited our room with a gift! We can hardly wait to return again this year. It is a great place to stay for a family, the suites make it affordable compared to individual rooms for a family of 4 or more.

We rented a private one-bedroom unit at The Imperial through VRBO (#39889). It was clean, bright & updated throughout. Our unit was spacious, had 2 bathrooms & 2 lanais with partial ocean views and a full (new) kitchen. Check in (& out) was friendly & efficient. Location can't be beat, even though there is alot of construction & noise right now. They quit by supper time & start up by 7:00 a.m or so. The towel exchange was handy. No need to bring beach towels as you can get clean ones daily. The lobby area is very nice although the pool area is tiny, but who needs it with the beach so close. The large ABC store at the base of the building carries everything.I would not hesitate to book again. It was perfect for our family of four including 2 older teenagers.

I live on the North Shore, but our kids were coming and wanted to stay in Waikiki..so we traded a timeshare week to the Imperial so they would have a week in the city......I don't even know where to begin. Please know this review has basically NOTHING to do with the construction, other than at this time none of the 2 bedroom sliders can be opened to get any air and at 7:00AM until 5:00 PM you feel from the drilling like your having a 10 hours root canal done. I have stayed in many places some wonderful, some not so wonderful...but NEVER have I ever seen anything like this that was paid for in my life. the unit was a two bedroom, because we thought we might stay in the city with them a few days....The kitchen was totally inadequate, although I would have never cooked in it because it was so filthy!The bathrooms.. were such a diaster that you didn't need to flush the toliet because they were running so badly, everything was gone by the time you got your pants up. In one bathroom the sink was literally held up with two by fours. Enough tiling was missing from the vanities that you could not classify them as tiled. In the one bedroom thee was a full bed and that was it..no dresser..no nightstands or lamps, just a overhead light. To get around the bed you had to do the side shuffle..so practice up! The matteras in both bedrooms were so bad, that no one sleep the entire time and when you used the let out couch, it was at such a tilt that it felt like you were going to slide right off. A trip to the jacquzzi..was only to find it with gren water. Trust me it was NOT sanitary. Yes, you only sleep there..BUT when you are paying money..it should be a place that is clean and that you can get some sleep. As a resident of the Island of oahu, I must say I am embarrassed to say...DONT STAY THERE!! Log onto the VRBO and find yourself a nice place for the same price.

Sure - its in the middle of a construction war zone - but the accomodations were great, the staff very friendly and accomodating - very close to the beach at a backstreet price - clean condo unit - everything worked - pool was very clean - and an ABC store right off the lobby kept us in fresh fruit, guava juice, and sweetbread whenever we wanted without a schlepp across town. Two Starbucks within 3 block radius - great breakfast special at Chief's Hut at Outrigger Hotel - one block away - 4 blocks from Kalakaua Ave and massive shopping choices.Booked our stay through a broker in LA - very scary - had to pay w/ check - no credit. Taking kids to HI for first time with disabled spouse so was terrified that I would show up to no room avail - was I ever wrong. Staff was absoulutely charming from valets (car retrieval never took more than 3 minutes) to front desk staff to housekeeping. Now about that war zone - major multi year construction project on hotels on north and west side of Imperial - was noisy as heck during day 6:30 AM - 5:00 PM - but we were at the beach or upstairs at pool - could still see water and sunset from lanai - but if you are not an early riser not sure what you can do. Daughter and I had a blast watching construction activity - huge crane, full day concrete pour, etc.Overall - glad we avoided the "huge city" atmosphere of Hilton Hawaiian and overpriced closets at other hotels - we had plenty of room for 4 in 1 BR/2 BA suite. Met several "I come here every year" families at pool or on elevator - I hope to be able to say that some day - will return when possible

I knew that my friend and I would be staying in one of the small rooms. We had a murphy bed and couch. We were pleasantly surprised with our small ocean view from the balcony. It was quiet and roomy enough for us. The kitchen area makes the room feel bigger. The bathroom wasn't huge, but fit our needs. We didn't go to Oahu to spend the trip in our room. We had no problems with the staff. It was great being so close to the shops and beach. In the middle of everything! We wanted some nightlife and to be able to walk around w/o always needing a rental car. We did rent a car for part of the trip because we wanted to check out the whole island and I'm glad that we did. A lot of places were undergoing renovations or some sort of construction. This didn't affect our trip at all. We still had a great time and can't wait to go back! Snorkeling, horseback riding, hiking, relaxing - it was a great trip!

My stay at the Imperial Hotel was the worst experience. It basically put a big damper on my trip. It all started with loose change and dollar bills going missing within our room. We could handle that, but what really upset me the most was how we were treated like complete dummies when asking for help within the lobby area (especially the front desk). The day-shift staff at the front desk wouldn't give us the time of day when we would ask for directions to our destinations or bus times. They would simply give us an "I dunno, ask someone else". They were not hospitable at all, they made me feel extremely uncomfortable. The same day-shift clerk even accused me of losing a DVD rental that we didn't even rent. Later that day they found the DVD which was rented to another room, and not once did I get an apology. We were given dirty looks by the two day-shift front desk employees everytime we stepped off of the elevator for the rest of our trip. Also, I put up the 'do not disturb' sign one day while we went out to the beach, and I came back to find the towels in my bathroom replaced. This instantly made me mad, as we had money previously taken. We spent the next two hours going through our stuff making sure nothing was missing. Then, to top everything off, our checkout time was at 11 a.m., but unfortunately our flight didn't leave until 9:00 p.m. so reluctantly we had to leave our luggage with the hotel. When we arrived to pick up our luggage, we briefly looked through it all to make sure all of our belongings were still there. We did this within 10 minutes, as our shuttle bus had arrived early to pick us up. Everything looked fine, until I realized at the airport that I didn't remember seeing the macadamian cookies on top of my clothing when I searched before we left. When I arrived, I unpacked my luggage and sure enough, I discovered I was missing them. It wasn't too important but it really made me mad. My mom had asked me to bring home a couple of boxes of macadamian nut cookies (which are not available where I am from). They had opened up my suitcase and taken the cookies out when we left our luggage there. I packed them on top of my clothing. They had the nerve to steal from my bag! For all those planning a trip here, be very aware of your possessions. If you unfortunately have booked here, you'll understand what I mean when I say they really lack hospitality. I wouldn't recommend this hotel to anyone, not in a million years!

I was scheduled to be at this hotel for seven nights. Everyone of my requests for accomodations was denied. They did move us from the original room on the bottom floor to a room with a view of the parking ramp next door. I have returned to this hotel five times in the last seven years. Each time the service has deteriorated. This is the last time I will stay there. We left after three nights and checked into the Sheraton down the beach. We traded the view of the parking ramp for a view of Diamond Head and the ocean. The difference was total service and a view for a couple of hundred dollars more. It was well worth it. I have leaqrned my lesson. I hope the readers of this review will not limit the enjoyment a Hawaiian vacation can be by staying at this locaiton.Hawaii is a great place to visit. We return every year and enjoy the Aloha Spirit. We will not be returning to the Imperial Waikiki.

We stayed at the Imperial for 1 week on exchange. We unfortunately only had a view of a car park and at least the Pink Palace(Royal Hawaiian Hotel). However the room was great it was a Banyan room which is one bedroom with a murphy bed(a bed in the wall that pulls down) in the lounge. The kitchen is a good size.The gym is good the roof pool is adequate -good views and the owners lounge on the 26th floor has excellent views and computers for internet. The staff were very nice and friendly too. Everything is in walking distance,the beach the supermarket, abc shop downstairs, military memorial, Hilton Hawaiian Village etc.I would stay again for convenience although I did miss having a view. It looks like only rooms over about 22 floors would have a view or ones facing the beach. But if you don't spend a lot of time in your room it doesnt really matter.. Enjoy

We just got back from our vactation and had spent one week at the Imperial. We stayed on the 23rd floor and had a terrific view of the ocean. We would sit on our balcony (there were 2) and watch the surfers and boats every morning on the ocean. I was told only the floors 20 and up had ocean views. The condos are small, but we were out so much it never bothered us. The room was very, very clean. Maid service was only once a week, but they came every day to empty our trash and there was a portable vacuum in the room so we could pick up the sand ourselves. The staff was very friendly to us, gave us good advice and the valets were really quick to bring us our rental car. The entrance is hard to find and not clearly marked.The pool is very small (roof top) but we found very few people went in the pool so our family had it mostly to ourselves. The view was great on the top floor. The beach is only a block away. I found the beach terrific by the Imperial, really close to all the other hotels. Easy access to the beach and back, either through public assess paths or through the other hotels. Bottom line, this is not a top hotel, but we loved the casualness of the place and found that the service was really friendly. There is construction all around the hotel but our side didn't have any noise.

We have just returned from our vacation on Oahu, and I had to post my personal comment concerning The Imperial Hawaii Resort at Waikiki-Honolulu, HI.First and formost...this is the worst and dumpiest hotel I have ever stayed in! Usually we stay in moderate priced hotels such as: Comfort Inns, Days Inns and Holiday Inns, so we are not the type of people who normally stay in the so called 'best' hotels so our standards for a hotel requirements are mainly for good value, clean rooms & bathrooms and good service for the right price. However, at the The Imperial Hawaii Resort...these standards were not meet at all.The Imperial Hawaii Resort is a timeshare...I want to caution people NOT to buy into this resort...if you want to even call it a resort. You can book suites here if you are not a member of the time share program---which I would not recommend.We stayed in the 3rd level of the suites in the 'PALM SUITE' with a price range of: $258-$271. This so called suite had one bedroom, which hardly had room enough to get around the bed from one side to the other. There was no dresser in the bedroom...the TV had to be mounted on the wall. The bathroom adjoining the bedroom was so small that only one person could be in there at a time. I could've washed my hands, used the toilet and washed my feet in the shower (no tub) at the same time if I wanted too--that is how small it was. The sink--had no counter area at all to it, therefore I had to place toiletries items on top of the toilet tank! There was only room for a glass near the sink which we placed our toothbrushes in. In the living room there was a pull-down double bed, and small. Also in the living room was a small dinning table that was virtually useless because when the bed was pulled down we had to shove the table up to the window just to make room for the bed. The coffee table had to be slide up to the couch to make room to walk around the bed when it was pulled down. The dinning chairs (no arm chairs at all!) had to be moved each night to the kitchen area to make room for the bed. Again, the TV had to be mounted on the wall due to limited space in the living room area. As for the so called 'full kitchen' this again was a joke for a suite at this price range. There was a very small microwave, dishwasher and only a mini refrigerator that bearly had room for a few items. There was a stove with an oven on top of it that looked like it dated back to the early 70's and didn't work well at all! A coffee maker was in the kitchen....but no coffee, sugar or creamer was provided. We had never stayed at a hotel, let alone a resort, with a coffee maker in our room and coffee was not provided. Even in a Comfort Inn...coffee, sugar, creamer are in the rooms that provide coffee makers...but not at this 'resort'!!! So bring your or plan on buying a small jar of instant coffee for $3.95 in the store and plan on drinking it black or you will have to buy sugar and creamer too.The second bathroom was not much better...the only difference with the size of it compared to the one connected to the bedroom was it did have a bathtub with shower. However, the sink-counter area was still no larger.As for cleaniless....we had to call housekeeping the minute we got into our suite because both bathrooms had mildrew on the tiles! Housekeeping did show up later that evening while we were at dinner and 'tried' to clean it...but there still remained mildew on many of the tiles throughout our stay. Mainly due to the fact that these bathrooms had not been cleaned properly in years and not renovated at all since the 70's when it was first built, therefore the mildew was so embedded in the grout of the tiles...it would not come out! The maid service here was only once in 7 days....therefore we only received clean towels once or we could personally go down to housekeeping and get more on our own! Remember...this is a 'resort' suite and with a price range of almost $300 a night and we had to get our own towels. Even when we called housekeeping and asked for more..they refused to bring them to us. The floors were only vacuumed once in 7 days. The linens on the beds were never changed in 7 days and the bed in the bedroom was only made up once. The pull-down bed was never made up or linens changed at all in 7 days! The bathrooms were only cleaned once in 7 days...other than the extra cleaning we got because of our complaint of the mildew on the tiles our first day, which the bathrooms should've been cleaned properly to begin with before we checked into the suite!As for location...it is a very good location for right downtown Waikiki shops and dinning. Only one block to many nice places, but there was construction all around the hotel, therefore making it loud with noise first thing in the morning till 5 PM at night. This, I understand, will not continue forever...but during our visit it was very disturbing.The walk to the beach was short...but the beach was the worst I have ever been to with major hotels right on it and located on Waikiki. The sand (if you call it that) going into the ocean was full of large rocks--not pebbles--but ROCKS! So large in fact that if I wasn't careful walking into the ocean...I could've turned my ankle. So needless to say, we did not swim at this beach...but ended up walking down quite a ways to a better beach. So much for a close beach area to our hotel---NOT! If you wanted to sit on the beach...that was limited too. The beach area was very small and was surrounded by a stone wall that went up to a walkway because of the massive erosion of the beach in this area. So sandy beach area was extremely limited.The pool area was not much better. There was no view of the ocean but out one window. There is a huge, tall brick wall all around the pool area due to the fact it is located on the roof of the building. I understand that this wall is necessary for safety sake, however with the safety glass or plastic that is available (and used) in many hotels with this same type of pool arrangement nowadays, I would think this hotel could've upgraded the pool-wall with this type of material instead of a brick wall with very small windows. I felt very closed in...even though I was totally outside and on top of a building! The only redeeming thing I can say about this hotel is on the top floor there is an 'owners lounge'--which only time share holders can use. Regular hotel guest are NOT allowed in this lounge. Our friends who we went with are time sharers. So we were able to use the lounge. The view of the ocean was wonderful from the lounge. Nice arm chairs...tables and couches were in it...also a pool table. We stayed here quite a bit because we felt like we had more room to move around in than in our suite...which is very sad in my opinion seeing the cost of the suite in which we stayed in! Even enjoying this lounge had it's downfalls...no personal privacy. Other time share members used it also (as they should) so we felt like we had to talk quietly as we would in any other public place.As I stated before, our friends are time share holders and traded their points to be able to go to Hawaii. They had no choice about where they could stay...therefore they had to stay at this hotel. Needless to say, they were shocked, disappointed and very embarrassed about this hotel, because they had invited us to come with them on vacation. They stated that this hotel was the worst they have ever stayed in in their 7+ years as time share holders. That is why I felt it necessary to warn others about this hotel. Even if you have no intentions in buying into the time share...please reconsider even staying here at all. It is a DUMP!!! I am not being hard with saying this...only truthful. I would've much rather been a few blocks further from the beach and had a much nicer suite or even a single room with 2 queen beds in it than have stayed here.Kay Mixson

My original timeshare destination to Puerto Rico was not granted and had to settle for Waikiki. This is my 4th trip to Hawaii; previous trips were to Maui and Kauai. I was booked at the Imperial and was a little apprehensive about staying there after reading the reviews and receiving a letter from RCI about the construction around the resort. I even tried to change it at last minute, but was unable to. I am used to staying at 5 star hotels, but boy, was I pleasantly surprised. It was not at all what I expected. The front desk was very courteous; they even allowed us to check in early. The parking attendants were always very friendly. We had a one bedroom suite on the 12th floor. The room was clean...no mold in the showers; and even the murphy bed was comfortable. We did not have a full front ocean view but we were able to get a glimpse of it from the lanai. We were in a city high rise and most of the views were of the surrounding hotels. However, the sunset view from the 26th floor of the owner's lounge all but made up for it. The noise and construction was to be expected; and driving through it was no different than driving in Los Angeles, San Francisco or New York City. As for the noise, again, Waikiki is a city. If you've ever stayed in any other hotel in a busy city, noise is a given...even without the construction. We enjoyed our shopping sprees. The resort is conveniently located a few steps from the "Rodeo Drive" of Waikiki.However, no one goes to Hawaii to stay in the hotel. A short drive away from Waikiki on H1 will take you to the most beautiful beaches in the world. We found our own secluded beach spot and spent a day swimming and snorkeling...even saw a few sea turtles for free! Our last night was spent on Waikiki beach (which was 100 steps from the resort) watching the sunset and listening to the Hawaiian music being played at the Outrigger. It was such a wonderful vacation, we decided to purchase a timeshare week at the Imperial for 1/4th the price of other resorts in the area. It is an older hotel and not a 5-star world class resort; but once the dust from construction settles in 2007, the Imperial Resort will be in the middle of one of the hottest spots in Hawaii...a place that is definitely worth returning to every year.

Exchanged a week and did not expect the Ritz. Room was adequate but needed updating. View was of a construction site but we had been warned and this was not a major issue as we spent most of the time away from hotel, just need to know this if you are looking to use hotel.Construction also going on around the hotel so some of the sidewalks closed.Biggest grumble was maid service only had one clean mid week and that was poor to say the least. Had to get fresh towels and as maid only came once also had to take old ones down. Lifts were slow and only three for 26 floors, pool was tiny. Plus was location it was as stated 100 yards from the beach and travel firm in hotel lobby provided good value and good trips (recomend full island tour with ENOA especially if you get Shannon as the tour guide). Also free scuba lesson given in pool which went down well with my son.Staff were ok but did not go that extra mile, did not seem happy in their jobs when compared to nearby hotels, even the few fish in the tank behind them looked fed up! Only one restauarant on site and that was a Dennys. ABC store was a bonus and the staff there always had a smile.Entrance of the hotel was a bit of a non-event, difficult to find on first night.If I was an owner here I would have serious questiions about service and standards this is the only time I have not had daily maid service.If you want basic standards then you will do fine with this hotel, island was great will go back and hopefully travel to other islands but will not use the Imperial again

Not bad at all. We went mid July 05'Well, You get what you pay for. We took this from a trade for our "nice" Orlando timeshare. The place was OK for the price. Great location. Within 100 feet from the beach. Getting to the beach was easy and access was easy going through one of the other hotels. One problem was the beach was crowded. Go to a different beach off the beaten path away from all the hotels. They were unbelievable.The place was clean and safe. The Air Cond. worked well. The TV was fine (one TV, only in the living room not in the bedroom) but, we did not go to Hawaii for TV. We were on the 20th floor. No real view. The balcony felt a little unsafe. I would liked to have went on there but did not feel safe on it. You do have to get your own towels, no biggie, The pool is a little small. But, what the heck.There is still allot of construction going on Lewers St. The room does not matter you will hear noise in the daytime. The staff I thought was great. The activities desk was really, really helpful. Denny’s for breakfast once is cool. The Starbucks was an even better. Pearl Harbor was interesting. Go early the lines are long. One last thing, we did the Island tour from our own limousine. The driver was a guy named Mike in a green limo call Kermit. This was by far the best part of out trip. Mike was an excellent guide and this was probably the best thing we did. Fresh fruit in the limo, all the sites, etc. On a scale from 1 to 10. 10 being the highest, I would rate this hotel a 6 ½.Hey like I said if you want the 4-5 star hotel and, are willing to pay for it. This is not the place. If you want a decent clean place, this is your best deal.

We exchanged into the Imperial for a week. Could not have asked for a better location, except to be right on the beach. Building is shoulder to shoulder with many high end luxury hotels that are on the beach - making it just across the street from the beach. Short walking distance (5 minutes) to International Market Place, lots of stuff in between. Rooms were spacious, even though they warn you that they are on the smaller side for condos. Comfortable beds, plenty of linens, clean floors, and well stocked supplies. All was wonderful, but not luxurious.Staff was friendly and helpfull to us when we checked in/out and when we asked for recommendations on dining/activies in the area. Maid service was daily and adequate. Drawback #1 was that the lower floors and back end rooms did not have any views of the water. #2 parking was an additional charge. Most hotels charge for parking so that's not a huge drawback. $15 per day in March 2005. #3 Constuction on Lewers makes it harder to walk down the street.Vacationer beware - "Welcome Breakfast" is code for "we'd like to sell you a timeshare."

My husband and I stayed at the Imperial in 1999 on our honeymoon. I will agree it was not paradise but it was a nice place. It was close to the beach and easy to get to all other attractions. It was very clean and the staff was helpfull. Yes the pool needs some work but hey your in Hawaii who needs a pool when you have the entire ocean at your disposal. As a parent of 4 children vacations are a luxury and I felt that we were well taken care of for the amount we spent. if I had wanted all the extras and to be treated like gold then it was up to me to pay the price. We chose to spend less so we got less and still had a wonderfull time. For the amount of time spent in our room, it was worth putting the extra money on the many other activities we enjoyed which I must say the hotel staff helped us arrange. I would definately return. keep up the great work of catering to the not so rich population who still wants a get away!

I have read these reviews and as an owner and occupant at least every other year, I have to disagree with the negativity. The noise level can be annoying if you are right above the night club, but it's Waikiki the party island. Also, the rooms I have had each stay have always been clean (no mold etc.) and the staff has been very helpful and courteous. Actually, each year I return , I see the same faces. It must be okay if the employees stay on year after year. If people want a five star hotel, then make a reservation at a five star. This resort is comfortable, safe and in a great location. I love going there.

We stayed at the Imperial for 8 days Sept. 22-29 in a "Palm Suite" which is a 1 bedroom/2 bath, 2 lanai's on the 7th floor. We made our reservations through Expedia. The suite was a little small for 4 people but we didn't spend a lot of time in the room so it was not a problem. It was very clean and the maid service was great. You just have to make sure when your booking a room that it includes daily maid service. We found some people there that did not get that provided because of the company they booked their reservation through. These are time share units so depending upon their agreement, it makes a difference what type of hotel amenities you might receive. Using Expedia it listed all the property and room amenities. Its a great location to all shopping, restaurants and less than 1 block to the beach. The staff was all very friendly and helpful. We would definitely stay there again.

We have just returned from our second year (15 day stay) at the Imperial. I sometimes wonder what some of these reviews are really all about. If you book a bed sit room, that is what you get. For goodness sake, pay the extra and get a one bedroom apartment. We were on the second 16 floor again, great airconditioning, daily maid service with extra towels each day ( may I suggest, if you tip the maid you would get decent service). The queen size bed in the bedroom was firm but excellent, the kitchen spotless and the location FOR THE PRICE, second to none. Who wants a pool when you are across the road from the beach. There are only two "five star" hotels in Ohau, the Halakalani and the the Kahala Mandarin, both three times the price of the Imperial. If you want five star any where in the world you pay for it. For our money the Imperial is great value and where we will stay again. In reference to one review, I agree, the Imperial is not the place for a honeymoon, and it doesn't advertise itself as a romantic honeymoon hotel, rather, an apartment complex for a relaxed hoilday.

My husband and I went to Hawaii on our honeymoon and had the one bedroom "suite". The higher you are in the Imperial the better it gets. However, not even on the 17th floor where we were, were the rooms that great. Many things were dirty in the room (sheets, kitchen stuff, etc.) and the air conditioning didnt work. The so-called-bed drove me over the edge. There was no way I was going to spend our first night on our honeymoon sleeping on that! Most of the staff was nice, but I'm from NY so everyone seemed nice to me in Hawaii. We did get moved to a different room b/c of everything that went wrong so that was nice. However, If it were up to me I would have switched hotels because there is no way I would pay what they ask for the rooms in taht run down place.

My wife and I were on our first trip to Hawaii for our honeymoon. When we checked into our room, the first thing we found was that the bed pulled out from the wall. We shrugged it off, we were in Hawaii! Well we pulled back the blankets and sheets to find that the linens were dirty with hair, and God only knows what else (stains of some sort)! Imediately after my wife noticed a large amount of bugs on the counter in the kitchenette. I called the front desk and explained the situation and was told someone would be right up. About 45 mins. later I had to call the front desk again. We had just gotten in and wanted to go eat. Someone showed up about 15 mins. later with new linens, that I had to change, and bug spray, which they sprayed on all the dishes and silverware in the drawers, along with anything on the counters!!! All this was useless to us now until we washed it! Not long after I noticed that the room was not cooling down at all, the Air Conditioning did not work! I called the front desk again and told them that I wanted a new room, but I would wait until the next day. It gets better. I was going to make a cup of tea for my wife, when i went to use the coffee pot, There was a slimy layer of something in the pot. At this point my wife started crying and when I asked her what was wrong she said "I hate this place." Well that was enough of this. I went to the desk and told them that I wanted a new room Immediately. The manager took care of it, personally showing me the new room (it was an upgrade to a larger room with a real bed). She was not very friendly about this, as if it was my fault and I had no right. Well this new room was clean. But there are general things with the hotel that are terrible as well. The pool on the 27th floor is advertised as "having a great view" but there is nto a great view except through some windows that are about chest level in the wall. The Spa did not work properly and although the pool was clean, it was very small and old. Guest only recieve housekeeping ever 4th day, which would be okay if you could get towels, ect. You have to go to the housekeepers room and get them yourself if you need it. There is only dial up internet access. No breakfast included unless you go to the "welcome" that they have 2 times a week and have people try to sell you time share in this aweful place. I would not recommend this place to anyone. It is worth a little extra money to go someone nice and be treated the way guest should be treated! For a little more, and in some cases, less you get better hospitality!!!!!!!!

we have stayed at the Imperial twice and thoroughly enjoyed both visits. The first time we used a friend's timeshare and it was great to be able to use the "owners room" upstairs. Although we weren't able to do that the second time, the location, the view and the friendly staff more than made up for it. They have the most heavenly smelling lotion in the rooms, I couldn't get enough of it!

First time to Hawaii, we stayed at the Imperial for 5 nights in late July 2004. I had been stressed out for weeks after reading these boards but didn't know the area well enough to find another affordable hotel. As things turned out, we had a decent room, nothing fancy, but no "critters" and good maid service. We were pretty high up (20th floor) which seems to make a difference. The bar downstairs was rowdy but once you know what to expect you can cope. You can't beat the location and when I got back home I compared the prices to some of the neighboring hotels, and it is 1/2! Good value for your dollar!

In June of 2004, we stayed at the Imperial in the Hala Suite on the 8th floor. We had set our reservations up a year in advance and asked for a room above the 17th floor. We confirmed this 3 times before leaving for our trip. When checking in we were given the lowest room they had. We asked the clerk why we were given the bottom floor when we had asked for a room which would be high. She was very rude and said that she had no control over the rooms we were given and that if we wanted to change our location we should contact a number she provided for us. It seems to me that she should have called them for us and asked for another room. After all it is her job to help the customer, but she did not. That was our initial experience, but wait it gets better. We go to our room which sits on top of the Dennys roof. When sitting on the Lanai you smell smoke from their chimneys. So get use to greasey bacon, sausage, and pancake smells. Then we look in the bedrooms. The small bedroom had no air conditioning and was about 95 degrees in the afternoon. When we walked into the room, we looked up and the ceiling had boards nailed to it that were water stained and held in with screws. The same thing in the big bedroom. Huge boards brown and water stained and black mold growing around the edges. Both bathrooms had black mold growing on the ceilings and on the walls. One bathroom when you touched the mold on the ceiling your finger went right through. The mold was the worst part of the rooms. It was scary not knowing if it was toxic mold or not. When sleeping in the big room the view of the ceiling was terrible because you were looking at the boards with brown water stains and mold. We told the manager at the front desk and nothing was done about this. Once again not even offering a different room. The noise at night is loud. There is a bar down stairs and music at top decimal. So if you want a good night sleep don't count on it. My kids said the room reminded them of a ghetto room. The price is cheap for Oahu,but the service and rooms are very poor.

we just stayed at the imperial 7-1 through 7-11.ok - do not, if you can help it, stay on a lower room on the lewers side of the hotel. unless, you love the smell of denny's. we never got any fresh air that didn't have the smell of breakfast, lunch or dinner. i think they are open 24 hours and it sucks. i questioned guests higher up and they didn't smell denny's though - not fair!! fyi, we stayed on the 7th floor.we stayed in a hala suite - 2 bedrooms - 2 baths with all the kitchen things (stove, microwave, dishwasher, dishes, etc.) the rooms were small but clean, we had 4 kids in our room and the maid service always managed to clean it up. bless their hearts. the blue carpet is pretty yucky though. it is definitely not a 5 star but it is more spacious than other hotels we have stayed at on lewers for the same price. we did a $5 a day add on and it was so worth it .. unlimited local calls, dvd's, use of the safe.noise .. well that is a problem too. a lot of bars on lewers equals a lot of yelling and hollering once the buzz kicks in. i live in hermosa and am used to it but i bet a lot of you aren't. so beware. bring earplugs!!the staff was great - always courteous and definitely patient with kids. the valet service was great too - the smell in the garage they have to work in is dreadful .. tip them well. and the abc store is practically in the lobby. so anything we didn't have was super easy to grab when fixing dinner or other meals. those stores have pretty much everything .. truly amazing!!laundry was satisfactory, pool was small but it works. at least it's isolated being on the top of the hotel so you can control the surroundings. the beach is definitely better though. i guess that's good so you don't spend your vacation in hawaii at the pool!!we had a great time overall. i still prefer maui but waikiki is fun once in a while too. kids love it.so i hope this helps as i personally appreciate reading all of these reviews to make my travel experience better.

We spent a week here the latter part of April, 2004. Convenient to tour buses, restaurants, beach, everything. Had a problem getting a very important message but management looked into it and promptly explained and corrected problem. Really can't say that the staff, other than valet, was enthusiastic nor cheerful...they were just mediocre. We had a one bedroom with kitchen which was furnished with everything!!! Were were not there to spend a lot of time in the room nor did we want to prepare a gourmet meal. I would not hesitate to recommend this property because of the location. I think the person who said it was filthy and poorly furnished must have the wrong property. Though the furnishings were not lavish and perhaps smaller than what some people might expect, it was suitable for a couple who spent very little time in the room. We enjoyed the ABC store onsite, were disappointed with the Denny's restaurant in the hotel, but there are so many places to eat around there. I have no intention of returning to Hawaii (been there, done that!) but if I needed a place to stay for a week or two on Oahu, I would return to the Imperial. I rate it above average based on location! location! location!

What a dump! The two-bedroom timeshare was small, poorly funrished, didn't have a kitchen, and the noise from Lewers street is deafening, diesel fumes notwithstanding. The bed barely fit in the second bedroom. The bathroom was so small, we could barely set the toothpaste tube down! Everthing was rusted and dingy. Unbelievealbe! I rate this place in the bottom 5% of all of the places we have ever stayed! Don't take a chance!

The location was great, but the suite was a bit of a disappointment. The second bedroom did not have a cooling vent in it, and in the late afternoon with the heat of the day, the room was unbearable. Our view was from the 7th floor looking directly on to the roof of Denny's restaurant. The valet service was outstanding!

We stayed at the Imperial for a week recently. Pros: location - extremely convenient to the beach, to restaurants, to shopping; large room; mostly clean; great view from a certain spot in the room and on the lanai; staff was courteous (though not especially friendly) Cons: bathroom - extremely small and cramped, poor lighting, narrow storage shelves directly above the toilet (be careful nothing falls in), shower water temperature difficult to regulate; we had a pet in our room in the form of a very large cockroach (a good 2 inches long, and add another 3 if you count the antennae)(no exaggeration!); cable was often out completely or poor reception (they were trying to fix this); the pool was disappointing - the supposedly great view was only visible through small windows in the concrete-block wall surrounding the pool area...you could not see the great view from the pool or the deck chairs, you had to stand up and peer out the little windows to see it; staff was not especially friendly (although they were courteous); a surprising amount of street noise (and we were on a pretty high floor) All in all it depends what you want. You absolutely can't beat the location, and what you get for your money is not bad. But, I have stayed in smaller, friendlier, cheaper, just-as-clean, simpler hotels with almost as good a location in Waikiki and have found more aloha there. That's where I'll return next time, not to the Imperial.

My partner and I have just returned from our fifth visit to Hawaii and our first but not our last at the Imperial. What a fantastic find. A great one bedroom apartment, with a full murphy bed right across the road form the most expensive hotel in Waikiki, the Halakalani for less than half the price.I booked the apartment via the internet and the Imperial lived up to everything it promised on line. They gave us a great room with a great view, daily maid service and friendly staff. You really are made to feel welcome. There are only two comments that I would make. There is a labour dispute happening at present bewteen the hotel and the union and there were some protest marches outside the hotel and secondly the exterior of the building does need a paint. Having said that it is without doubt the best value in Waikiki. I hope not too many people read this as it may be booked out next year. Thanks again to the Imperial.A fantastic holiday

The Imperial is steps from the beach and almost everything else we wanted to do while in Waikiki. There is even a store at the entrance where we could buy everything we needed from groceries to souvenirs. We rented a car for only one day during our stay in order to drive around the island. We were very pleased with our Bayan suite, especially the two lanais. It was a little on the small side, but we spent most of our time on the beach and exploring. Most importantly, it was clean! An added bonus was free local calls and free use of the in-room safe. The Imperial staff was very happy to answer all the questions we posed during our week-long stay. We would return to this nice hotel again!

I travel extensively and have stayed in a variety of accomodations. I first visited the Imperial through an exchange. It is an excellent location, shared by several expensive hotels such as the Sheraton Waikiki. The personnel make you feel like a valued guest, and go out of their way to make you feel at home and to assist you. I enjoyed it there so much that I went home, thought it over and then called to buy a week's unit on a resale. I have never regretted it. I always look forward to returning. Whether for a week or a few days at the daily rate, you will find the Imperial has a variety of accomodations to meet your needs just steps from the beach and easily accessible to all activities.
